questions.question: A patient underwent cholecystectomy for gallstones 2.5 years ago. She now presents with symptoms of obstructive jaundice. Investigation reveals a stone in the common bile duct. What is the stone most likely to be?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Recurrent Explanation: The given scenario, where a patient has a history of cholecystectomy (gallbladder removal) for gallstones 2.5 years ago and is now presenting with obstructive jaundice and a gallstone in the common bile duct (CBD), indicates a case of recurrent type of Common Bile Duct Stones (Choledocholithiasis) . Types Retained common bile duct stones Detected within 2 years of cholecystectomy Recurrent common bile duct stones Detected after 2 years of cholecystectomy (Option D) Clinical features Charcot’s triad : Pain + Fever + Jaundice Reynauld’s pentad: Mental status changes + Hypotension + Charcot’s triad Biliary colic: A sudden, severe, colicky pain in the right upper quadrant that radiates to the back and shoulder, precipitated by a fatty or heavy meal, and can last for a few hours. Darkening of the urine and lightening of the stools. Steatorrhea, or fatty stools Pruritus (itching), loss of appetite, weight loss, nausea, and vomiting Investigation Ultrasound: Useful for detecting gallstones and CBD dilation but has limited sensitivity for CBD stones. MRCP: Non-invasive, excellent for visualising biliary tree anatomy and pathology. ERCP: Highly sensitive, both diagnostic and therapeutic for CBD stones. PTC: Used when ERCP is not feasible, such as post-gastrectomy patients or unsuccessful ERCP attempts. EUS: Invasive but accurate for diagnosing choledocholithiasis. Blood Tests: ↑ bilirubin, ↑ alkaline phosphatase, and ↑ white blood cell count indicate choledocholithiasis and possible complications like cholangitis. Treatment Endoscopic Management: ERCP with sphincterotomy and stone extraction; stenting if necessary. Percutaneous Removal: Used when endoscopic access is difficult. Surgery: Options include laparoscopic and open choledocholithotomy, choledochoduodenostomy, and choledochojejunostomy. Complications Cholangitis Pancreatitis Liver Damage Biliary Stricture Gallstone Ileus MRCP of CBD stone ERCP of a distal CBD stone Primary (Option A) forms inside the common bile duct (CBD), with brownstones being the most common type. These stones are often associated with underlying conditions such as primary sclerosing cholangitis or Caroli disease. Secondary (Option B) are those that form in the gallbladder and later migrate into the common bile duct (CBD). The most common type is cholesterol stones, which can subsequently move into the CBD. Tertiary (Option C) are formed within the bile ducts as a result of bacterial or parasitic infection.

questions.question: The following procedure is performed for the management of?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Distal cholangiocarcinoma Explanation: The given image depicts the Pylorus Preserving Whipple’s Procedure (Pancreaticoduodenectomy) , which is used in the management of distal cholangiocarcinoma. Structures removed: Head of the pancreas, the first part of the small intestine (duodenum), the gallbladder, and a portion of the bile duct. Types: • Pylorus-Preserving Whipple Procedure • Non–Pylorus-Preserving Whipple Procedure Indications Pancreatic Cancer: Commonly treated with Whipple if cancer is localised to the head of the pancreas. Chronic Pancreatitis: when uncontrolled by medical management. Tumors in Pancreas/Surrounding Areas: Includes duodenum, distal bile duct (distal cholangiocarcinoma), and ampulla of Vater. (Option C) Procedure Steps Tumor Assessment: Explore the abdomen to assess tumor size, location, and spread. Resection: Remove the head of the pancreas, duodenum, gallbladder, and part of the bile duct; this may include partial stomach resection. Lymph Node Dissection: Remove and examine nearby lymph nodes. Reconstruction Pancreaticojejunostomy: Connect the remaining pancreas to the jejunum. Hepaticojejunostomy: Connect common bile duct to the jejunum. Gastrojejunostomy: Connect stomach to jejunum. Anastomosis Principles Tension-Free Connection: Achieve mucosa-to-mucosa connection for healing. Order of Anastomoses: Pancreaticojejunostomy → Hepaticojejunostomy → Gastrojejunostomy Stent Placement: May use internal/external stents for small ducts. Complications • Pancreatic Fistula: Major issue; managed with somatostatin analogues. • Delayed Gastric Emptying • Bleeding, wound infection • Reoperation, increased mortality • Dumping/Bile Reflux: Common after non-pylorus-preserving Whipple, the pylorus-preserving method has uncertain benefits. Advanced gastric carcinoma (Option A): Treatment depends on tumour location. For proximal tumours, extended gastrectomy with D2 lymphadenectomy is done; for middle tumours, total

questions.question: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy and was discharged after removing the drain tube on the first postoperative day. On day two, the patient came back to the hospital with complaints of increasing abdominal pain with tachycardia and was febrile on examination. On ultrasound examination, there was a 5 x 5 cm collection in the subhepatic space. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct answer C) Bile leak Explanation: The given findings are highly suggestive of a bile leak , which is one of the most common early complications of laparoscopic cholecystectomy , occurring when bile escapes from an injured cystic duct stump or accessory bile duct . Infection (Option A) Would take more time (5–7 days post-op) to develop and is less likely to cause localized fluid collection early . Surgical Site Pain (Option B) Would not cause fever, tachycardia, or fluid collection on imaging. Retained Gallstones (Option D) Can cause biliary colic or cholangitis , but does not usually present this early with localized fluid collection ; more common after weeks to months . Reference: Bailey and Love short practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 1252, 1253

questions.question: What would be your approach in managing a patient who is a 40-year-old woman with a 5 mm gallbladder polyp detected on abdominal ultrasound, but no gallbladder stones? The patient is overall healthy and shows no symptoms.
questions.explanation: Correct answer A) Regular follow-up every 2 months: Explanation: Management Approach for Gallbladder Polyps Polyp Size Management <6 mm Regular follow-up (USG every 6–12 months for 2 years) 6–9 mm Follow-up every 3–6 months , consider cholecystectomy if growth or risk factors ≥ 10 mm Laparoscopic cholecystectomy (higher malignancy risk) Any size + symptoms or high-risk features Laparoscopic cholecystectomy Polypectomy (Option B) Not feasible since the gallbladder lacks mucosal resection capability like the colon. Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy (Option C) Only indicated if: Polyp ≥ 10 mm Rapid growth (>2 mm/year) High-risk features (PSC, age >50, sessile polyp, associated gallstones) Open Cholecystectomy (Option D) Only needed if there’s suspicion of malignancy or difficult laparoscopic access . Reference: Bailey and Love Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 1247, 1248.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common side effect of cholecystectomy?
questions.explanation: Correct answer C) Steatorrhea Explanation: Complications of Cholecystectomy Category Complication Description/Features Early (Intraoperative & Immediate Postoperative) Bile Duct Injury Accidental damage to the common bile duct (CBD) leads to bile leakage or strictures (More common in laparoscopic cholecystectomy). Hemorrhage Bleeding from the cystic artery or liver bed; managed with hemostasis or blood transfusion if severe. Bowel Injury Unintended injury to the duodenum or colon , is rare but serious. Anesthesia-related Complications Aspiration, respiratory depression, hypotension , and arrhythmias. Early Postoperative (0–7 Days) Infection (Wound/Port-Site Abscess) Fever, erythema, tenderness at the incision site. More common in diabetics or immunocompromised patients. Bile Leak (Biloma) Fever, abdominal pain, nausea , and localized fluid collection on imaging. Often from cystic duct stump or accessory bile duct injury . Subhepatic Collection (Abscess) Fever, RUQ pain, and tachycardia ; requires percutaneous drainage . Retained Gallstones Residual gallstones in the bile duct can cause biliary colic or cholangitis postoperatively. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) & Pulmonary Embolism (PE) Due to prolonged immobilization , leading to leg swelling or sudden dyspnea (Prevent with early ambulation, anticoagulation). Late Postoperative (>7 Days – Months/Years) Steatorrhea (Fatty Stools) (Option C) Most common long-term issue due to continuous bile secretion , leading to fat malabsorption . Post-Cholecystectomy Syndrome (PCS) Persistent dyspepsia, bloating, diarrhea, or RUQ pain due to bile reflux or remnant stones. Biliary Strictures Chronic narrowing of the CBD , leading to jaundice and cholangitis . Chronic Diarrhea Related to altered bile acid metabolism , may require bile acid sequestrants (e.g., cholestyramine). Increased Risk of Colorectal Cancer (Debatable) Some studies suggest a mild increase in colon cancer risk due to altered bile acid metabolism , but evidence is weak . Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) (Option A) Not a common direct complication of cholecystectomy; it could occur due to severe infection or intraoperative hypotension, but it is rare. Osteoporosis (Option B) No direct link; chronic fat malabsorption (as in severe bile acid diarrhoea) can lead to vitamin D deficiency, but this is uncommon in routine cholecystectomy cases. Colorectal Cancer (Option D) Some studies suggest a mild increase in colon cancer risk due to altered bile acid metabolism, but it is not a direct or common consequence of cholecystectomy. Reference: Bailey and Love Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 1251, 1254

questions.question: A young man presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain and 3 episodes of vomiting in the past 9 hours. He says that the pain radiates to the back and is partially relieved by bending forwards. The abdominal radiograph of the patient is given below which shows a ‘colon cut-off sign ’. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer B) Acute pancreatitis Explanation: Acute Pancreatitis Feature Description Definition Acute inflammation of the pancreas due to premature enzyme activation , leads to autodigestion. Common Causes ( Mnemonic: "I GET SMASHED" ) I diopathic, G allstones (most common), E thanol, T rauma, S teroids, M umps, A utoimmune, S corpion sting, H yperlipidemia/hypercalcemia, E RCP, D rugs (thiazides, azathioprine). Clinical Features Severe epigastric pain (radiates to back, worsens after food), nausea, vomiting, fever . Severe cases: Cullen’s Sign (periumbilical bruising), Grey Turner’s Sign (flank bruising), Colon Cutoff Sign (gas-filled, distended transverse colon with abrupt cut-off at splenic flexure due to inflammation). (Option B) Diagnosis (Atlanta Criteria) ≥ 2 of 3 criteria : (1) Lipase >3x ULN (more specific than amylase), (2) Epigastric pain , (3) Imaging (CT/USG/MRI) evidence . CT scan (best for complications), Ultrasound (detects gallstones). Severity Classification Mild: No organ failure, Moderate: <48 hrs organ failure, Severe: >48 hrs organ failure. Management IV Fluids (Ringer’s lactate), NPO (Bowel Rest), Pain Control (IV opioids), and Enteral feeding are preferred over TPN. ERCP only if gallstone pancreatitis with cholangitis. No routine antibiotics unless infected necrosis. Complications Early (<1 week): SIRS, Shock, ARDS, Renal failure, DIC, Hypocalcemia. Late (>1 week): Necrosis (sterile/infected), Pseudocyst, Abscess, Chronic Pancreatitis, Biliary obstruction. Acute hepatitis (Option A) Symptoms of acute hepatitis are fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, dark urine, light-coloured stools, joint pain, and jaundice. Acute colitis (Option C) In colitis, the mucosal lining of the colon becomes acutely or chronically inflamed. Symptoms of patients with colitis include watery diarrhoea, abdominal pain, tenesmus, urgency, fever, subjective fatigue, or blood in the stool. Intestinal obstruction (Option D) Intestinal obstructions present with dilated bowel loops with multiple air-fluid levels on abdominal x-ray. Reference: Bailey and Love Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 1270- 1273

questions.question: A 40-year-old man is brought to the casualty with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back for the past 1 day and has had 3 episodes of vomiting. The pain radiates to the back and is slightly relieved in the sitting forward position. The following signs are seen on examination and lab investigations reveal elevated lipase and amylase. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer C) Acute pancreatitis Explanation: The image shows Cullen’s sign , which is superficial edema with bruising in the subcutaneous fatty tissue around the peri-umbilical region, as well as the Grey Turner sign, which is flank ecchymosis. These signs are indicative of acute pancreatitis . Acute pancreatitis is characterised by pain in the abdomen that radiates to the back and is relieved in the sitting forward position. Elevated lipase and amylase are seen in acute pancreatitis. Acute Appendicitis (Option A) Pain typically starts as periumbilical and later localizes to the right lower quadrant (RLQ) (McBurney’s point). No back radiation or

questions.question: Identify the procedure shown in the image:
questions.explanation: Correct answer B) Whipple’s procedure Explaantion: The procedure shown in the image is Whipple’s procedure or pancreaticoduodenectomy. It is the primary surgical treatment for pancreatic cancer. The head of the pancreas, most of the duodenum, a portion of the bile duct, the gallbladder, and associated lymph nodes are removed. Whipple's pancreaticoduodenectomy involves resecting the tumour along with the 'C' loop of duodenum up to DJ flexure, proximal jejunum, head of the pancreas up to the neck, and partial gastrectomy, followed by three anastomoses: Pancreaticojejunostomy, Hepaticojejunostomy and Gastrojejunostomy typically performed for a mobile growth without metastasis. Berger’s procedure (Option A) In Beger’s procedure all of the head of the pancreas is removed but the bile duct, stomach and duodenum are preserved. Frey’s procedure (Option C) This procedure includes head coring (a portion of the head of the pancreas is incised). The Duodenum is spared. Pancreatic division (Option D) The image shown indicates Pancreaticoduodenectomy and not pancreatic division. Reference: Sabiston’s Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 1556-1559 Images: Image 1: https://commons.wikim edia.org/wiki/File:Diagram_showing_the_parts_removed_with_a_Whipple%27s_operation_CRUK_337.svg Image 2: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Illustration_of_Whipple_procedure.webp

questions.question: Identify the procedure shown in the image below.
questions.explanation: Correct answer B) Pancreaticojejunostomy: Explanation: The procedure shown in the above image is pancreaticojejunostomy. Puestow's operation is indicated for diffuse chronic pancreatitis and dilated pancreatic duct. The duct is opened wide, strictures are cut open, stones are removed, and it is anastomosed to one of the loops of jejunum. This is a by-pass procedure. It preserves both endocrine and exocrine functions. Gastrojejunostomy (Option A) It is the anastomosis of the body of the stomach to the first loop of the jejunum, by passing the duodenum. This procedure does not include the pancreas. Pancreatic Ileostomy (Option C) is done in case of pancreatic duct obstruction, and the pancreas is anastomosed to the ileum. This procedure is not indicated in the image. Duodenojejunostomy (Option D) It is a procedure done to anastomose a part of the duodenum to the jejunum to bypass an obstruction in the duodenum. This procedure is not indicated in the image. Reference: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/318295858_Longitudinal_Pancreaticojejunostomy_Puestow_Procedure

questions.question: A 36-year-old man presents with dull aching epigastric pain. He gives a history of acute abdominal pain following a binge of alcohol 5 weeks back, which was managed conservatively. On examination, he appeared icteric, and a firm mass was palpable in the epigastrium. His CT scan is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer A) Pancreatic pseudocyst Explanation: Pancreatic pseudocyst is a complication seen after 2 weeks of an acute pancreatitis attack. It is commonly seen in alcoholism. The cyst is usually located between the stomach and transverse colon, between the stomach and liver or Behind or below the transverse colon. Clinically a tense cystic mass in the epigastrium, umbilical region or left hypochondrium can be seen. Large choledochal cyst (Option B) Choledochal cyst is a congenital cyst and is not caused due to alcoholism. It is not seen as a tense mass in the epigastrium. Gastric duplication cyst (Option C) It is a congenital cyst and is not caused by alcoholism. It is seen usually in relation to the distal region of the greater curvature. There is no clinically evident tense mass near the epigastrium. Mesenteric cyst (Option D) This cyst is congenital Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557594/

questions.question: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 42-year-old woman who came with symptoms of fever, vomiting, and right hypochondriac pain, which radiates to the neck? She has experienced similar episodes in the past, and a positive Murphy's sign was observed during the examination.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Acute cholecystitis Explanation: Murphy's sign : when we place the fingers on the right hypochondrium and ask the patient to take deep inspiration. At the height of inspiration, there is a sudden catch. This catch is due to an inflamed gallbladder coming in contact with the abdominal wall. This produces pain. In the case of acute cholecystitis, there is inflammation of the gallbladder, and Murphy's sign is positive. Murphy’s sign is not positive in carcinoma of the gallbladder (Option B), peptic ulcer (Option C), or acute appendicitis (Option D), as it is specifically associated with acute cholecystitis. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1235, 1236, 1244

questions.question: What is the most appropriate next step in the management of a female patient who has abdominal pain, multiple gallstones with no thickening of the gallbladder wall as seen on ultrasound, a common bile duct diameter of 12mm, serum bilirubin level of 0.8, alkaline phosphatase level of 380, and a 5-fold increase in GGT?
questions.explanation: possibility of choledocholithiasis (stones in the common bile duct). The elevated alkaline phosphatase and significantly raised GGT levels also indicate some degree of biliary obstruction. MRCP can accurately assess the CBD and help identify the presence, location, and size of any stones within the duct. It can also evaluate the pancreatic duct for any associated pathology. By obtaining this information, MRCP can guide further management decisions and determine the most appropriate intervention, whether it's endoscopic or surgical. ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) (Option B) ERCP can be therapeutic and used for stone removal, it is typically reserved for cases where there is a clear indication for intervention, such as symptomatic choledocholithiasis or evidence of biliary obstruction with significant symptoms or abnormal liver function tests. Endoscopic ultrasound (Option C) EUS can be useful for evaluating certain conditions, such as pancreatic tumours or staging of gastrointestinal malignancies, it is not the primary modality for assessing gallstones or the biliary system. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy (Option D) in this case, the focus is primarily on the evaluation of the biliary system. Therefore, performing a cholecystectomy without further assessment and identification of possible choledocholithiasis would be premature. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1237- 1242

questions.question: A 40 year old woman presented with jaundice, fever, and abdominal pain. She is suspected to have cholangitis. Which of the following apart from abdominal pain makes up Reynold pentad? 1. Fever 2. Jaundice 3. Hypotension 4. Altered sensorium 5. Hematemesis 6. Melena
questions.explanation: Jaundice 3. Hypotension (Shock) 4. Altered mental status (Confusion, delirium) 5. Right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain Cholangitis Aetiology Often due to obstruction in the biliary tree, leading to bacterial infection by organisms like Klebsiella, E. coli, Enterobacter, Pseudomonas, and Citrobacter species. Symptoms Charcot's triad - pain, jaundice, fever Additional tenderness in the epigastrium and right hypochondrium is common. Severe Form: Reynolds pentad - persistent pain, fever, jaundice, shock, and altered mental status Indicates acute obstructive suppurative cholangitis. Lab Findings Elevated white blood cell count, bilirubin, and alkaline phosphatase levels. Chronic cases may show lobar or segmental atrophy or hypertrophy. Recurrent Pyogenic Cholangitis More common in East Asian populations, caused by intrahepatic stones and infections Risk factors include parasitic infections like Clonorchis sinensis and Ascaris lumbricoides. 2, 3, 4, 5 (Option B) Includes hematemesis , which is NOT a feature of Reynold’s Pentad. 1, 3, 4, 5 (Option C) Misses jaundice and includes hematemesis , which is NOT a feature of Reynold’s Pentad 1, 2, 4, 5) (Option D) Includes hematemesis , which is unrelated to cholangitis. I Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1253 Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 1515 SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 643

questions.question: Which of the following statements about hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is/are correct? 1. TACE(Transarterial chemoembolization) is used for multinodular lesions 2. Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm 3. The incidence of HCC is increasing 4. NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC
questions.explanation: TACE (Transarterial Chemoembolization) is used for multinodular lesions. True TACE is used in intermediate-stage (BCLC B) HCC with multiple nodules and preserved liver function (Child-Pugh A/B). 2. Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm. False Lenvatinib is a systemic therapy for advanced HCC (BCLC C) . Small (<3 cm) tumors are treated with resection, RFA, or liver transplant . 3. The incidence of HCC is increasing. True The incidence of HCC is rising globally due to increased metabolic syndrome, NAFLD/NASH, obesity, and hepatitis B/C . 4. NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC. True NAFLD/NASH are leading non-viral causes of HCC . They can cause HCC even in non-cirrhotic livers due to chronic inflammation. 1, 2, 3 (Option A) It includes the incorrect statement that Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm. Lenvatinib is an approved systemic therapy for advanced HCC 2, 3, 4 (Option B) It includes the incorrect statement that Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm. 1 and 2 (Option D) It does not include the correct statement that NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC. Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1208, 1215 https://journals.lww.com/hep/fulltext/2018/01000/aasld_guidelines_for_the_treatment_of.32.aspx

questions.question: What is the most helpful test to identify the underlying cause in a 56-year-old patient with obstructive jaundice, who presents with a distended gall bladder, dilated common bile duct, and enlarged intrahepatic biliary radicles on ultrasound?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography Explanation: Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) is: A non-invasive imaging modality. Excellent for visualising the biliary tree and pancreatic ducts . Particularly useful in obstructive jaundice to evaluate: Site of obstruction Cause (e.g., stones, strictures, tumours) Extent of biliary dilatation It does not require contrast injection into the ducts and has no risk of pancreatitis or infection , unlike ERCP. INVESTIGATIONS - CHOLEDOCHAL CYST Endoscopic Ultrasound (Option B ruled out) The first imaging test that is performed. Confirms the presence of the cyst. Reveals anatomical details, including bile duct and pancreatic duct relationship. Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) Non-invasive imaging technique. Provides detailed images of the gallbladder and biliary system. Highly sensitive (>90%) and specific (>99%) for identifying common bile duct stones. Visualizes biliary anatomy and the extent of dilatation. Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP): (Option D ruled out) Invasive procedure with endoscope and contrast material. Diagnostic and therapeutic capabilities (tissue sampling, decompression, treatment of choledocholithiasis). Effective but has a complication rate of up to 10%. Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography (PTC) Invasive procedure with a needle directly into the liver. Useful for intrahepatic biliary disease or when ERCP is not feasible. (Option C ruled out) Helps delineate surgical anatomy and enables drainage catheter and stent placement. CT SCAN Mainly to see the intrahepatic biliary system Other Tests Hepatobiliary nuclide Scanning Liver Function Tests

questions.question: What should be the subsequent course of action in the management of a female patient who experienced abdominal pain and increased heart rate three days after cholecystectomy? Her white blood cell count is 11000 cells / mm^3, and an ultrasound examination revealed a 5x5 cm accumulation of fluid in the sub-hepatic space on the right side.
questions.explanation: Correct answer B) USG-guided pigtail catheter drainage Explanation: The next step in managing a woman who presented with abdominal pain and tachycardia, with a fluid collection in the right sub-hepatic space seen on ultrasound, is USG-guided pigtail catheter drainage as this is a case of bile duct injury following cholecystectomy. Ultrasound-guided pigtail catheter drainage offers several advantages, including improved accuracy in locating the fluid collection and minimizing the risk of complications. Antibiotics and send home (Option A) The presence of a fluid collection and symptoms suggestive of postoperative complications necessitates intervention rather than sending the patient home with antibiotics alone. Laparoscopy and re-exploration (Option C) are not the first-line management options for a fluid collection in the subhepatic space. Less invasive measures like drainage should be attempted first. ERCP and T-tube placement (Option D) are indicated in biliary tract-related issues, which may not be the primary cause of the fluid collection in this scenario. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery (28th Edition) page 1252

questions.question: Which of the following is the classical triad of acute cholangitis? ↑ WBC ↑ WBC, ↑ Bilirubin
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Pain, jaundice, fever Explanation: Pain, jaundice, fever - this triad, known as Charcot's triad- indicates cholangitis. Cholangitis Aetiology Often due to obstruction in the biliary tree, leading to bacterial infection by organisms like Klebsiella, E. coli, Enterobacter, Pseudomonas, and Citrobacter species. Symptoms Charcot's triad - pain, jaundice, fever Additional tenderness in the epigastrium and right hypochondrium is common. Severe Form: Reynolds pentad - persistent pain, fever, jaundice, shock, and altered mental status Indicates acute obstructive suppurative cholangitis. Lab Findings Elevated white blood cell count, bilirubin, and alkaline phosphatase levels. Chronic cases may show lobar or segmental atrophy or hypertrophy. Recurrent Pyogenic Cholangitis More common in East Asian populations, caused by intrahepatic stones and infections Risk factors include parasitic infections like Clonorchis sinensis and Ascaris lumbricoides. Pain, jaundice, shock (Option B): This option is incorrect as shock is not part of Charcot's triad but is part of Reynolds's pentad. Fever, jaundice, ↑ WBC (Option C): ↑ WBC, although it does occur in cholangitis, is not a component of Charcot's triad. Pain, ↑ WBC, ↑ Bilirubin (Option D): ↑ Bilirubin, although it does occur in cholangitis, is not a component of Charcot's triad. Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1253 Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 1515 SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 643

questions.question: An alcoholic patient presented with severe abdominal pain. Pancreatitis was suspected, and a CT scan revealed lesions with fluid collected near the body of the pancreas. Which of the following enzymes is most likely to be elevated?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Serum lipase Explanation: The patient's severe abdominal pain and CT scan showing fluid-filled lesions near the body of the pancreas suggest an inflammatory process, diagnosed as Pancreatitis , with elevated serum lipase levels. Clinical Diagnosis (Requires 2 of 3): Abdominal pain is strongly suggestive of acute pancreatitis. Serum amylase and/or lipase (more specific) level at least 3 times the upper limit of normal. Imaging findings characteristic of acute pancreatitis. X-ray Features Sentinel loop sign : Dilated loop of small intestine near the inflamed pancreas due to localised ileus. Significance : Early indicator of acute pancreatitis on X-ray. Sentinel loop sign Colon cut-off sign : Abrupt termination of gas in the colon at the splenic flexure, with collapsed distal colon loops. Significance : Suggests localised pancreatic inflammation, causing colonic spasm as an indirect sign of acute pancreatitis Investigations of Choice: Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) : Primary tool for assessing pancreatic necrosis, peripancreatic inflammation, fluid collections, and complications. Most reliable for staging and detecting complications. It may underestimate necrosis if done in the first 24 hours. Morphological Types (Revised Atlanta Classification 2008): Interstitial oedematous pancreatitis : Mild form with pancreatic oedema and swelling but no necrosis. Necrotising pancreatitis : Severe form involving pancreatic parenchymal necrosis, associated with higher morbidity and mortality. Serum GGT (Gamma-Glutamyl Transferase) (Option A) is elevated in liver disease, especially in cases of alcohol abuse, but it's not specific to pancreatitis. CEA (Option B) , carcinoembryonic antigen, is a tumour marker not typically elevated in pancreatitis. Serum bilirubin (Option D) may be elevated in biliary obstruction or liver disease; it is not a primary marker for pancreatitis.

questions.question: A 54-year-old female patient presents with abdominal pain and bilious vomiting. She had a history of abdominal hysterectomy 2 years back. On examination, abdomen auscultation revealed high-pitched bowel sounds. Investigations showed air within the biliary tree. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Gallstone ileus Explanation: The patient, with a history of abdominal hysterectomy 2 years ago, presents with abdominal pain, bilious vomiting, high-pitched bowel sounds on auscultation, and investigations revealing air within the biliary tree, indicating Gallstone ileus. A rare complication of cholelithiasis (0.4%) caused by the impaction of one or more gallstones within the gastrointestinal tract, is more common in the elderly and women. Pathophysiology: Acute cholecystitis → erosion of inflamed tissues → Formation of a cholecystointestinal fistula → Gallstone ileus Small gallstones typically pass through the intestines, but stones 2–5 cm in size can become impacted, usually in the terminal ileum or at the ileocecal valve. Clinical Manifestations: Acute, intermittent, or chronic episodes of partial or complete gastrointestinal obstruction. Signs of obstruction include dehydration, abdominal distension and tenderness, high-pitched bowel sounds, and obstructive jaundice. (Option A) Diagnosis: Plain Abdominal Radiograph: Partial or complete intestinal obstruction Pneumobilia or contrast material in the biliary tree Calcified gallstone with position changes on serial films (tumbling sign) CT Scan: Superior sensitivity (up to 93%) Shows abnormal gallbladder with air, air-fluid level, or fluid accumulation with an irregular wall (Option A) Management: Management of intestinal obstruction Enterolithotomy: The most common surgical procedure A longitudinal incision on the antimesenteric border proximal to the site of impaction Gallstone is brought to a non-edematous bowel segment by gentle manipulation and extraction. Cholecystoenteric fistula resection only if the patient is stable and there are residual gallstones that may cause infection or recurrent ileus. Adhesive intestinal obstruction (Option B) occurs when scar tissue from previous abdominal surgery causes bowel loops to stick together, leading to obstruction. It typically presents with symptoms of bowel obstruction (pain, vomiting, distention) but would not show air in the biliary tree. Ischemic enterocolitis (Option C) results from reduced blood flow to the intestines, often due to arterial blockage or low blood pressure. It causes diffuse abdominal pain, tenderness, and sometimes bloody diarrhoea, but does not cause the air in the biliary tree. Diverticulitis (Option D) is inflammation or infection of small pouches (diverticula) in the colon. It usually presents with lower abdominal pain, fever, and changes in bowel habits, and does not cause air in the biliary tree.

questions.question: ERCP is least useful in the diagnosis of:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Acute Pancreatitis without choledocholithiasis Explanation: Acute pancreatitis is inflammation of the pancreas, often linked to biliary causes like gallstones or choledocholithiasis; however, when choledocholithiasis is absent, and no bile duct obstruction is present, ERCP is not typically recommended. ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) is an invasive diagnostic and therapeutic procedure used to examine and treat disorders of the bile ducts , pancreatic ducts , and gallbladder . In the given case, non-invasive imaging like abdominal ultrasound, CT scan, or MRI is sufficient to assess the pancreas and biliary tree, and ERCP is reserved for patients with evidence of bile duct obstruction . Recurrent pancreatitis (Option A) can be caused by bile duct stones, pancreatic duct abnormalities, or strictures. ERCP helps by identifying obstructions, structural changes, and stones in the bile duct or pancreatic duct . It also allows therapeutic interventions such as stone removal or stenting of the bile duct. Therefore, ERCP is often used in recurrent pancreatitis if there is suspicion of biliary causes. Unexplained jaundice (Option B) can arise from a variety of causes, but one of the most common is obstruction of the bile duct, often by stones, tumours, or strictures. ERCP is an excellent diagnostic tool for identifying the cause of jaundice. Periampullary mass (Option C) is a growth near the Ampulla of Vater, and ERCP is particularly useful in the diagnosis of these as it provides detailed imaging of the ampulla of Vater and helps identify the location, extent, and nature of the mass, aiding in further management decisions. Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 154 SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Pages 675 - 68

questions.question: A patient presents with pain in the right upper quadrant on the second postoperative day following a cholecystectomy. Evaluation reveals a collection in the subhepatic space. A bile leak is suspected. Which of the following is the best investigation for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) ERCP Explanation: In the context of a suspected bile leak after cholecystectomy , the best investigation is typically ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) It can help confirm the presence of a bile leak, localise the site, and allow for therapeutic intervention, such as stenting , which may resolve the leak. Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) Definition It is an invasive diagnostic and therapeutic procedure used to examine and treat disorders of the bile ducts , pancreatic ducts , and gallbladder . Indications It allows for visual assessment of the duodenum and ampulla of Vater. Allows biopsies, stone extraction, and other Interventional procedures like sphincterotomy, biliary stenting, and biliary stricture dilation. In Jaundice Less suitable for jaundiced patients as it is invasive Imaging Type Provides dynamic information during contrast introduction Image MRCP (Option A) is a non-invasive imaging technique that can help visualise bile ducts, but it doesn't provide the same ability for therapeutic intervention as ERCP . HIDA (Option C) (Hepatobiliary Iminodiacetic Acid scan) is useful for evaluating biliary patency and assessing bile flow . Though it can be used for detecting bile flow abnormalities, it cannot be used for therapeutic management, hence ERCP is generally considered the best for diagnosing and managing bile leaks. CECT (Option D) can be used to detect collections or fluid accumulation and its evaluation but it lacks the therapeutic intervention that ERCP can offer. Additionally, CECT involves radiation exposure and may not be the optimal choice when a more specific investigation like ERCP is available.

questions.question: According to Strasberg's classification of bile duct injuries, injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct with bile leak is:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Type C Explanation: Right aberrant posterior sectoral duct = accessory duct not part of the main biliary confluence Transected with bile leak = consistent with Type C injury This is often missed intraoperatively and presents with bilious drainage postoperatively. The Strasberg classification of bile duct injuries Type A (M/C) (Option A ruled out) Cystic duct stump leak or leak from sub-vesical duct of Luschka Type B (Option Bruled out) Ligation or occlusion of aberrant right sectoral duct Type C (Option C) Transection without occlusion of the aberrant right sectoral duct Type D (Option D ruled out) Injury to the lateral wall of the Common hepatic duct Type E E1 to E5 Bismuth classification

questions.question: A patient with recurrent pain in the right hypochondrium, nausea, and vomiting is diagnosed with biliary dyskinesia. Which of the following is least useful in the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) USG Explanation: Biliary dyskinesia is a functional disorder of the gallbladder, characterised by abnormal motility and diagnosis is typically made through tests that evaluate gallbladder function rather than its structure. USG is good for detecting structural abnormalities, but it does not assess gallbladder function. It presents with intermittent upper abdominal pain and nausea, particularly after eating, when your gallbladder attempts to contract (biliary colic) and the insufficient bile in the intestine leads to bloating, nausea, vomiting, and poor digestion, especially after consuming fatty foods. HIDA scan is useful in diagnosis, as it evaluates gallbladder function using a radioactive tracer. (Option B ruled out) ERCP (Option A) is not the first-line test for biliary dyskinesia, but it is used to assess biliary dysmotility by using a manometry. It is also useful for visualizing the biliary ducts and can help rule out anatomical causes of biliary pain; it also provides an opportunity for therapeutic interventions if needed. Post-surgery follow-up (Option D) is not used to diagnose biliary dyskinesia but is important for monitoring recovery and addressing complications, as well as for managing and assessing the patient's condition after surgical intervention. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 156

questions.question: A 5-year-old child with Wilson's disease is being considered for liver transplantation. Which of the following is not a parameter in the selection criteria for transplantation? µ mol/L

options.D: Jaundice less than 7 days before the development of encephalopathy

questions.explanation: Correct Answer D - Jaundice less than 7 days before the development of encephalopathy Jaundice is not a parameter in the Nazer Prognostic Index for liver transplantation. It’s the other parameters (age, PT, and bilirubin levels) that are considered critical in assessing prognosis and transplant eligibility. NAZER prognostic index: It is used to calculate the prognosis of the liver disease and determine the need for liver transplantation. A failed medical treatment indicates the need for liver transplantation. It is indicated in a patient with acute liver failure due to Wilson disease with a NAZER prognostic score of 9 or more. Laboratory measurement (Other options ruled out) Score (in points) Normal value 0 1 2 3 4 Serum bilirubin 0.2-1.2 mg/dL <5.8 5.8-8.8 8.8-11.7 11.7-17.5 >17.5 Serum aspartate transferase 10-35 IU/L <100 100-150 151-200 201-300 >300 Prolongation of prothrombin time (seconds) <4 4-8 9-12 13-20 >20 Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Pages 648, 2552.

questions.question: An 80-year-old woman presented with fatigue. Imaging revealed a scleroatrophic gallbladder with impacted stones and a large stone in the common bile duct, causing dilation of the biliary tree. What is the next step in management?

options.A: Immediately take up the patient for cholecystectomy

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography Explanation: The next step in the management of this patient is ERCP , which is used to relieve biliary obstruction caused by the stone in the common bile duct. It is a procedure that combines endoscopy and fluoroscopy to visualise and treat conditions affecting the bile ducts and pancreatic ducts. It allows for the removal of common bile duct stones, dilation of strictures, and placement of stents to relieve biliary obstruction. It has both diagnostic and therapeutic capabilities. Stones up to 12 mm can usually be removed by Endoscopic Retrograde. Choledocholithiasis Investigation Ultrasound: Useful for detecting gallstones and CBD dilation but has limited sensitivity for CBD stones. MRCP: Non-invasive, excellent for visualising biliary tree anatomy and pathology. ERCP: Highly sensitive, both diagnostic and therapeutic for CBD stones. PTC: Used when ERCP is not feasible, such as post-gastrectomy patients or unsuccessful ERCP attempts. EUS: Invasive but accurate for diagnosing choledocholithiasis. Blood Tests: ↑ bilirubin, ↑ alkaline phosphatase, and ↑ white blood cell count indicate choledocholithiasis and possible complications like cholangitis. Treatment Endoscopic Management: ERCP with sphincterotomy and stone extraction; stenting if necessary. Percutaneous Removal: Used when endoscopic access is difficult. Surgery: Options include laparoscopic and open choledocholithotomy, choledochoduodenostomy, and choledochojejunostomy. Complications Cholangitis: Bacterial infection due to obstructed bile flow, leading to fever, chills, right upper quadrant pain, and jaundice. Pancreatitis: Inflammation of the pancreas due to obstruction at the ampulla of Vater. Liver Damage: Prolonged obstruction can cause biliary cirrhosis and liver failure. Biliary Stricture: Chronic inflammation can lead to the narrowing of the bile ducts. Gallstone Ileus: Large gallstone eroding into the intestine, causing mechanical obstruction. Immediately take up the patient for cholecystectomy (Option A): Cholecystectomy is the surgical removal of the gall bladder. When there is an active obstruction of the bile duct, the focus should first be on relieving the biliary obstruction before considering cholecystectomy. Once the obstruction is addressed, the patient can undergo cholecystectomy to prevent future complications. Wait and watch (Option C) is not appropriate in this case because the patient has an impacted stone in the common bile duct with associated dilation of the biliary tree and is symptomatic. If left management is delayed, it could lead to complications. CT scan (Option D) may provide additional information about the extent of the biliary tree dilatation and the presence of other abnormalities, but it does not address the immediate need for intervention to relieve the biliary obstruction.

questions.question: A 35-year-old man presented with recurrent episodes of fever with chills. The MRCP image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Primary sclerosing cholangitis Explanation: The patient's age, male predominance, along with MRCP findings of (beading) multiple irregular stricturing and dilatations of the bile duct, suggest Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis . Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC) PSC is characterised by inflammation and obliterative fibrosis of extrahepatic and large intrahepatic bile ducts, with dilation of preserved segments. Demographics It commonly occurs in individuals aged 30-50 years. Has a male predominance of 2:1. Pathogenesis It suggests an immunologically mediated process supported by circulating autoantibodies and T lymphocytes in the periductal stroma, as well as associations with HLA-B8 and ulcerative colitis . A mix of environmental & genetic factors may trigger bile duct injury. Increased risk of PSC in first-degree relatives indicates a genetic component. Activated T cells from ulcerative colitis mucosa may migrate to the liver, targeting bile duct antigens. Changes in the intestinal microbiome or infections may alter cholangiocytes, causing inflammation. Atypical perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (pANCA) are Clinical features Common symptoms include fatigue, pruritus, and jaundice. Nearly 50% of patients are asymptomatic at diagnosis, often identified through elevated serum alkaline phosphatase. Ascending cholangitis, chronic pancreatitis, and chronic cholecystitis may also occur. Fibrosis can progress to cirrhosis over 10-15 years. Characteristic findings ERCP/MRCP shows the beaded appearance of bile ducts Biopsy, Early features: Periductal "onion skin" fibrosis & inflammation Portal edema & bile ductular proliferation Later stages show progressive fibrosis leading to biliary cirrhosis and obliterative cholangitis, resulting in "vanishing bile duct syndrome" Associated conditions Ulcerative

questions.question: A young sheep farmer presents to the OPD with pain in the right upper part of the abdomen. Upon examination, there was tenderness and enlargement of the liver. Blood investigations show eosinophilia, elevated liver enzymes, and abdominal ultrasound, as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Hydatid cyst Explanation: The clinical presentation described, along with the ultrasound provided her,e suggests Hydatid disease . The given ultrasound shows a characteristic waterlily sign, indicating a cyst with a detached membrane floating within the cyst cavity, which is a hallmark of stage CE 3. Hydatid cyst Causative agent Echinococcus granulosus Commonly Affected Organs Liver (most common site, about 60-70% of cases) Lungs (second most common site) Other organs (rare but possible): Brain, spleen, kidneys, bones, and peritoneum Clinical Features Asymptomatic Phase: Common due to slow cyst growth. Symptomatic Phase: Liver Involvement: Mostly right lobe; Abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, obstructive jaundice, portal hypertension. Lung Involvement: Cough, chest pain, dyspnea, hemoptysis, pneumothorax. Investigations Imaging Studies: USG is the first-line imaging modality, particularly for liver involvement. Features: Echinococcal cyst wall shows double echogenic lines separated by a hypoechoic layer (double contour) CT Scan MRI Serological Tests: ELISA Immunoblotting Other tests: Casoni Intradermal Test ARC5 Immunoelectrophoresis Amoebic liver

questions.question: Which of the following is a tumour marker of pancreatic cancer?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) CA 19-9 Explanation: CA 19-9 is a tumour marker that is commonly associated with pancreatic cancer . Pancreatic cancer tumor marker: Carbohydrate Antigen 19-9 (CA19-9) Usage : Establish a baseline level for monitoring. Characteristics : Not highly specific or sensitive. Useful for detecting recurrence if initial levels are raised Tumor markers Tumor marker Associated conditions Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) (Option B ruled out) Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) Hepatoblastoma Yolk sac tumour (endodermal sinus tumour) Nonseminomatous germ cell tumour of testis ↑ AFP: abdominal wall defects, neural tube defects ↓ AFP: associated with trisomy 21, 18, and 13 β -HCG Nonseminomatous testicular germ cell tumours (choriocarcinoma, embryonal cell carcinoma, mixed germ cell tumour, seminoma) Ovarian cancer: choriocarcinoma (gestational trophoblastic disease) Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) Colorectal cancer Pancreatic cancer Breast cancer Lung cancer (especially in non-small cell cancers) Gastric cancer Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) Prostate cancer Benign prostatic hyperplasia Prostatitis Calcitonin Medullary thyroid cancer (both sporadic and associated with MEN 1 and MEN 2) Alkaline phosphatase Metastases to bone or liver Paget disease of the bone Placental alkaline phosphatase Seminoma Lactate dehydrogenase Ovarian cancer (dysgerminoma) Testicular germ cell tumours (both seminoma and nonseminoma) Lymphomas Ewing's sarcoma Neuron specific enolase (NSE) (Option A ruled out) Neuroendocrine tumors Small cell lung cancer Carcinoid tumour Neuroblastoma CA 19–9 (Option D) Pancreatic adenocarcinoma Colon cancer Cholangiocarcinoma CA 15–3 and CA 27–29 (Option C ruled out) Breast cancer CA 125 Ovarian carcinoma Other gynecologic malignancies S-100 protein (S100A) and (S100B) Malignant melanoma SMRP Mesothelioma Reference: Bailey and Love Short Practise of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1283,1284, 1571, 1572, 1364, 1618. Robbins and Cotran’s Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 336.

questions.question: A patient underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy for cholelithiasis. A picture of the resected gall bladder is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Gall bladder carcinoma Explanation: The given image shows a resected gall bladder with features suggestive of carcinoma, it is typically nodular and infiltrative , causing thickening of the gall bladder wall, which may extend to the entire gall bladder. It is often difficult to differentiate from chronic cholecystitis. Gall bladder carcinoma Risk factors Gallstones, (The risk of developing carcinoma in gallstone disease is 7-10 times higher than in the general population) Porcelain gallbladder, PSC, Abnormal pancreatic-biliary junction Presentation Often indistinguishable from benign gallbladder diseases Symptoms include: Biliary colic Cholecystitis (especially in older individuals) Jaundice (late-stage) Loss of appetite (late-stage) Palpable mass (late-stage) Lab investigation Non-specific indicators: Anemia Leukocytosis Slight increase in transaminases Tumor markers: Elevated CA19-9 Elevated carcinoembryonic antigen (in ~80% of patients) Diagnosis Ultrasonography (USG): Initial diagnosis CT Scans: Thorax, abdomen, and pelvis for confirmation and staging MRI/MRCP: For accurate preoperative staging PET Scans: To identify metastatic disease Staging & Biopsy Preoperative Staging: Crucial to assess local disease extent and rule out distant metastases Percutaneous Biopsy: Guided by radiological imaging for unresectable tumours Laparoscopic Examination: Detects peritoneal or liver metastases that preclude surgery Mixed stone in gall bladder (Option B) refers to gallstones composed of a mixture of cholesterol, bilirubin, and calcium salts. They are normally identified through imaging methods such as ultrasound and may not appear visibly as a carcinoma. Cholecystitis (Option C) refers to inflammation of the gall bladder, often due to gallstones or infection. It can present with acute symptoms like pain, fever, and nausea. Imaging shows gallbladder wall thickening (>3 mm), pericholecystic fluid, & ultrasonographic Murphy's sign. Choledocholithiasis (Option D) refers to the presence of stones in the common bile duct, and its diagnosis typically requires imaging to show stones in the bile duct.

questions.question: What is the term for a stone obstructing the cystic duct, causing dilation of the common hepatic duct, resulting in CBD obstruction and jaundice?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Mirizzi’s syndrome Explanation: The condition described in the question is known as Mirizzi’s syndrome . Mirizzi's syndrome is seen in 1% of all cholecystectomies, where a gallstone impacts the gallbladder wall, leading to compression and pressure necrosis. This often results in adherence to the common hepatic duct (CHD) or common bile duct (CBD) wall and can occasionally lead to a cholecystocholedochal fistula. It leads to biliary obstruction , which can result in jaundice and dilation of the bile ducts (CHD and CBD). Mirizzi’s syndrome Pathophysiology The gallstone usually impacts from the Hartmann's pouch, leading to compression of the CHD/CBD. Can also occur from the fundus of the gallbladder into the CBD. Clinical features Fever Abdominal pain Obstructive jaundice Upper abdominal tenderness on the right side Possible palpable soft, enlarged liver Csendes Classification Type I - Extrinsic compression of the CBD/CHD by a large impacted stone in Hartmann's pouch; IA- the presence of cystic duct IB- is obliterated cystic duct Type II - The stone has eroded the CBD/CHD less than 1/3rd of the circumference of the CBD/CHD, forming a fistula Type III - Involving up to 2/3rd of the circumference of CBD/ CHD Type IV - Cholecystocholedochal fistula (>2/3rd) involving the entire circumference of the CBD/CHD Type V - Cholecystocholedochal fistula with cholecystoenteric fistula without gallstone ileus (VA) or with gallstone ileus (VB) Investigations Ultrasonography (USG): Initial imaging to assess gallbladder and ducts. CT Scan: Provides detailed imaging of the biliary system. ERCP/ MRCP: Essential for delineating duct anatomy and identifying the site of obstruction. HIDA Scan: Useful for functional assessment of the biliary system. Findings: Dilatation of the intrahepatic biliary system with a block at the common hepatic duct (CHD). Acute cholecystitis (Option A) is inflammation of the gallbladder, typically due to gallstone obstruction of the cystic duct. While this condition can cause pain and tenderness in the right upper quadrant , it does not commonly cause dilation of the common hepatic duct or jaundice unless there is a secondary obstruction of the CBD or cystic duct. Porcelain gallbladder (Option B) refers to calcification of the gallbladder wall, usually due to chronic cholecystitis . This condition is associated with an increased risk of gallbladder cancer but does not cause biliary obstruction or jaundice due to stone impaction in the cystic duct. Cholesterolosis (Option C), also called strawberry gallbladder, involves lipid deposits in the gallbladder mucosa, leading to a characteristic appearance on imaging. It is often asymptomatic and does not typically cause biliary obstruction or jaundice .

questions.question: A 70-year-old woman had her routine follow-up, and her USG of the liver is shown below. She is asymptomatic at present but has a history of mild right hypochondriac pain, which is relieved by taking analgesics. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Gallstones Explanation: The most likely diagnosis is Gallstones , based on the USG findings of a thickened gallbladder wall with biliary sludge, acoustic shadowing and the patient's history of mild right hypochondriac pain that responds to analgesics. Gallstones can sometimes be asymptomatic or present with mild right upper quadrant pain , which is relieved by analgesics. This suggests biliary colic rather than an acute infection. Biliary sludge, often seen on imaging, is a precursor to gallstones and can occur due to stagnation of bile in the gallbladder, often in the presence of gallstones. Amoebic liver abscess (Option B) presents with fever , right upper quadrant pain , and liver enlargement . It is often seen in patients with a history of amoebic dysentery (entamoeba histolytica infection). The USG would show a hypoechoic mass in the liver, which is not consistent with the findings in this case. Hydatid cyst (Option C) is caused by Echinococcus tapeworm infection and is usually found in the liver. The USG appearance of a hydatid cyst typically shows water-lily signs multilocular cysts, or honeycomb patterns, which is not seen here. Symptoms include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and jaundice. Acute cholecystitis (Option D) presents with severe right upper quadrant pain , fever , and Murphy's sign (pain on palpation of the right upper quadrant). It generally presents more acutely and is associated with inflammation and infection , leading to more severe symptoms .

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with abdominal pain in the emergency room. . On examination, there is blackish discoloration involving the periumbilical skin . What is the most likely diagnosis for this presentation?
questions.explanation: and can cause severe abdominal pain. However, it typically doesn't lead to blackish discoloration of the perineal skin. Hypotension may occur in severe cases due to systemic inflammation and fluid shifts, but the perineal discoloration is not a common feature of acute pancreatitis. Presents with cullens sign Incorrect Options: Option B - Necrotizing Fasciitis: Deeper tissue injury, usually from anaerobic bacteria or S pyogenes . Pain may be out of proportion to exam findings. Results in crepitus from methane and CO2 production. “Flesh-eating bacteria.” Causes bullae and skin necrosis causing violaceous color of bullae, surrounding skin . Surgical emergency Option C - Chronic Pancreatitis: Chronic pancreatitis is a long-standing inflammation of the pancreas, often due to alcohol abuse or other underlying factors. It leads to persistent abdominal pain, digestive issues, and potentially complications over time. However, it is unlikely to cause the rapid onset of perineal skin discoloration and hypotension as seen in the given presentation. Option D - Traumatic Fat Necrosis: Traumatic fat necrosis can occur as a result of physical trauma to fatty tissues, leading to localized inflammation and tissue damage. While it can cause skin discoloration, it typically presents as a localized issue rather than involving the perineal skin. It's also less likely to cause the severe systemic symptoms, including hypotension, seen in this case.

questions.question: Identify the marked structure?
questions.explanation: (RHA) originates from the Proper Hepatic Artery and courses toward the right lobe of the liver . It runs behind the common hepatic duct and gives rise to the Cystic Artery , which supplies the gallbladder. Image-Based Identification: The marked structure is seen branching toward the right lobe of the liver , which aligns with the usual anatomical location of the Right Hepatic Artery . Its size and direction distinguish it from smaller branches such as the Cystic Artery . Right Hepatic Artery Feature Description Origin Proper Hepatic Artery (branch of Common Hepatic Artery) Course Runs behind the common hepatic duct and ascends toward the right lobe of the liver Branches Cystic artery (to gallbladder), Segmental branches to liver Function Supplies the right lobe of the liver and gallbladder Clinical Importance Injury during cholecystectomy can lead to hemorrhage or hepatic ischemia Cystic Artery (Option A): Incorrect because the cystic artery is a smaller branch of the RHA that supplies the gallbladder, whereas the marked structure is larger and directed toward the liver. Hepatic Duct (Option C): Incorrect because the hepatic duct is a biliary structure that transports bile, not an artery. Cystic Duct (Option D): Incorrect because the cystic duct connects the gallbladder to the bile duct system and does not match the marked arterial structure.

questions.question: Identify the stage of disease given in the image.
questions.explanation: cysts, membranes, or debris. The cyst wall may show signs of rupture or detachment. Imaging Characteristics: A mixed pattern with daughter cysts, floating membranes ("water lily sign"), or internal debris. This stage indicates an ongoing degenerative process of the cyst, with possible partial rupture. WHO-IWGE staging Gharbi classification Description Stage CE1 Type I Unilocular anechoic cystic lesion with double line sign Active CE2 Type III Multiseptated, "rosette-like" "honeycomb" cyst Active CE3 A Type II Cyst with detached membranes (water-lily sign) Transitional CE3 B Type III Cyst with daughter cysts in solid matrix Transitional CE4 Type IV Cyst with heterogenous hypoechoic/hyperechoic contents. No daughter cysts Inactive CE5 Type V Solid cyst with calcified wall Inactive Incorrect Options: Option A - Type 1: The cyst is small and filled with clear fluid, with no visible daughter cysts or debris. This represents the early, uncomplicated stage. Imaging Characteristics: A purely cystic lesion with smooth walls, no internal septations, or calcifications. Option C - Type 3: The cyst begins to mature, showing internal septations or a "honeycomb" appearance as daughter cysts start forming within the main cyst. Imaging Characteristics: Multiple small cysts within the main cyst, leading to a multilocular appearance. The cyst walls remain intact, and the fluid is still clear. Option D - Type 4: The cyst shows evidence of complete degeneration, with a solidified appearance. The cyst is often calcified and may no longer be active. Imaging Characteristics: A dense, calcified mass with no visible fluid or daughter cysts. The cyst is inactive or dead. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 75 SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 595

questions.question: Identify the disease?
questions.explanation: Incorrect Options: Option B - Renal tumor: Renal tumors, such as renal cell carcinoma, are solid masses in the kidneys that are malignant or benign. They are characterized by abnormal growth of cells rather than fluid-filled sacs. Option C - Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD): ADPKD is a genetic disorder characterized by the formation of multiple fluid-filled cysts in both kidneys. This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern and can lead to kidney failure over time. Option D - Hydatid cyst: Hydatid cysts are caused by a parasitic infection (Echinococcus) and are typically found in the liver or lungs rather than the kidneys. They are not associated with genetic predisposition. Reference: .

questions.question: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Identify the marked structure in the image.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Cystic duct Explanation: The marked structure is a Cystic duct. GB - Gall Bladder CA - Cystic Artery CD - Cystic Duct Calot's triangle, also known as the cystohepatic triangle, is an important anatomical area during gallbladder surgery. The boundaries of Calot's triangle are defined by: Cystic duct (lateral boundary) Common hepatic duct (medial boundary) The inferior surface of the liver (superior boundary) The contents of Calot's triangle typically include the cystic artery, which supplies blood to the gallbladder, and the cystic lymph node (Lund’s node). Identification of these structures is crucial during a cholecystectomy to avoid accidental injury to the biliary or vascular systems. Note: The term "hepatocystic triangle" is often used interchangeably with Calot's triangle. It emphasizes the inclusion of the liver's inferior surface as part of the boundaries, along with the cystic duct and the common hepatic duct.

questions.question: A 45-year-old alcoholic patient presents to the ER with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back. Blood investigations reveal increased serum amylase and lipase levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Acute pancreatitis Explanation: The patient's history of alcohol consumption, along with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back and significantly elevated serum amylase and lipase levels , points strongly toward acute pancreatitis. Acute pancreatitis: Clinical features: Pain ( severe , constant , and often resistant to common analgesics) . In about 50% of patients , the pain radiates to the back , and some patients may find relief by sitting or leaning forward . Nausea and vomiting are usually prominent, and retching may persist even with nasogastric aspiration. Examination findings: Patient's condition: well to severely ill with signs of shock and toxicity . Tachypnea , tachycardia , and hypotension are commonly observed. Mild icterus may suggest biliary obstruction (in gallstone pancreatitis). SIRS may be present Bluish discolouration ( Grey Turner’s sign or Cullen’s sign ). Abdominal distension due to ileus or ascites is common, and muscle guarding is often present. Diagnosis: Serum amylase level > 3x the normal value is strongly indicative. Serum lipase is more sensitive and specific than amylase. CECT scan is the gold standard for confirming the diagnosis. Management: Mild cases may be managed with IV fluids , analgesics , and antiemetics . Nil per os (NPO) is typically advised initially to avoid stimulating the pancreas. Antibiotics are not generally indicated unless there is suspicion of infection Management of severe cases: Admit to intensive care or a high-dependency unit for close monitoring. Aggressive fluid resuscitation is critical, guided by vital signs, urine output, and central venous pressure. Oxygen supplementation and serial blood gas analysis . If nutritional support is necessary, enteral feeding via nasogastric tube is preferred over parenteral nutrition. Management of specific complications: Antibiotics may be indicated if cholangitis or other infections are suspected. Prophylactic antibiotics should not exceed 14 days . If gallstone pancreatitis is suspected and there is biliary obstruction , ERCP should be performed within 72 hours . Complications: Shock , arrhythmias , ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome), renal failure , and DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation) . Metabolic derangements like hypocalcemia , hyperglycemia , and hyperlipidemia may occur. Peripancreatic fluid collection , pancreatic abscess , pseudocyst , and pancreatic necrosis . Pleural effusion , pancreatic ascites , and pancreatic haemorrhage (pseudoaneurysm) are also common. Incorrect Options: Peptic ulcer disease (Option A) typically presents with epigastric pain, but it doesn't radiate to the back & does not cause elevated amylase and lipase levels. Acute cholecystitis (Option C) presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, often with fever and nausea, but it is not typically associated with marked increases in amylase and lipase. This condition would usually show elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin. Pyogenic liver abscess (Option D) can present with fever and abdominal pain, but it does not typically cause significant increases in amylase and lipase. This condition would be more likely to show abnormal liver function tests and may be associated with other findings like fever or jaundice. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1272-1274

questions.question: A newborn presents with jaundice. Biliary atresia is suspected when jaundice is persistent and exceeds?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 2 weeks Explanation: Biliary atresia is a serious condition that causes bile ducts to become obstructed or absent, leading to cholestasis and liver damage. In newborns, jaundice that persists beyond 2 weeks is a key clinical sign of biliary atresia, as physiological jaundice typically resolves within the first 1-2 weeks of life. Extra-Hepatic Biliary Atresia: Also known as Non-Cystic Obliterative Cholangiopathy. Characterised by complete obliteration of extrahepatic bile ducts and intrahepatic ducts at the hilum. Typically appear by 2 to 6 weeks of age Jaundice (yellowish coloration of skin and sclera) Abnormally pale stools Dark urine Commonly associated with polysplenia or asplenia Investigations: Liver Function Tests: Increased conjugated bilirubin. Markers of cholestasis: 5' nucleotidase Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) GGT (Gamma-glutamyl transferase): Normal: Up to 40 U/L 4x elevation: Intrahepatic causes 10x elevation: Extrahepatic causes Exception: Low in PFIC type I and II Ultrasound: High-frequency USG (HUS) for neonatal cholestasis. Fasting USG is the gold standard when biliary atresia is suspected. Characteristic findings: Triangular cord sign (hyperechoic areas indicating fibrous/atretic bile duct) Non-visualized gallbladder/micro gallbladder/gallbladder ghost Radionucleotide Study: HIDA Scan (Hepatobiliary scan with Tc labelled imino-di-acetic acid): Used as a screening test. Decreased tracer excretion due to obstruction Phenobarbitone loading/priming (5 days) to improve tracer uptake Used as a screening test, not specific Best Investigation: Liver biopsy: IOC for confirming diagnosis. Surgical Management: Temporary procedure: Kasai procedure/hepaticojejunostomy Definitive management: Liver transplantation Kasai Procedure: Temporary procedure Creates communication between the liver and jejunum for bile drainage Should be performed within 8 weeks after birth Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1241 https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/liverextrahepaticbiliaryatresia.html Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page 2097-2099

questions.question: What is the most common complication of ERCP?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Pancreatitis Explanation: Pancreatitis is the most common complication of ERCP, with an incidence of approximately 4.3%. While post-ERCP pancreatitis is typically mild, it can become severe with extensive pancreatic necrosis in some cases. Complications of ERCP: Pancreatitis (Most Common) It can be severe, with extensive pancreatic necrosis Associated with a significant mortality rate Use of per-rectal indometacin/diclofenac to reduce risk Duodenal perforation (Option A) Haemorrhage post-sphincterotomy (Option C) Sepsis Cholangitis (Option B) Sphincter stenosis Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 156 SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 625

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum amylase and lipase levels. Which of the following should be avoided in the management of the given condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Administration of 5% dextrose Explanation: The clinical presentation suggests acute pancreatitis. In managing acute pancreatitis , administration of 5% dextrose should be avoided in the initial phase because it can excessively increase blood glucose levels. Elevated glucose can stimulate the pancreas and worsen the condition by increasing pancreatic activity. This can exacerbate inflammation and further damage the pancreas. Acute pancreatitis: Clinical features: Pain ( severe , constant , and often resistant to common analgesics) . In about 50% of patients , the pain radiates to the back , and some patients may find relief by sitting or leaning forward . Nausea and vomiting are usually prominent, and retching may persist even with nasogastric aspiration. Examination findings: Patient's condition: well to severely ill with signs of shock and toxicity . Tachypnea , tachycardia , and hypotension are commonly observed. Mild icterus may suggest biliary obstruction (in gallstone pancreatitis). SIRS may be present Bluish discolouration ( Grey Turner’s sign or Cullen’s sign ). Abdominal distension due to ileus or ascites is common, and muscle guarding is often present. Diagnosis: Serum amylase level > 3x the normal value is strongly indicative. Serum lipase is more sensitive and specific than amylase. CECT scan is the gold standard for confirming the diagnosis. Management: Mild cases may be managed with IV fluids , analgesics , and antiemetics . Nil per oral (NPO) is typically advised initially to avoid stimulating the pancreas. Antibiotics are not generally indicated unless there is suspicion of infection Management of severe cases: Admit to intensive care or a high-dependency unit for close monitoring. Aggressive fluid resuscitation is critical, guided by vital signs, urine output, and central venous pressure. Oxygen supplementation and serial blood gas analysis . If nutritional support is necessary, enteral feeding via nasogastric tube is preferred over parenteral nutrition. Management of specific complications: Antibiotics may be indicated if cholangitis or other infections are suspected. Prophylactic antibiotics should not exceed 14 days . If gallstone pancreatitis is suspected and there is biliary obstruction , ERCP should be performed within 72 hours . Complications: Shock , arrhythmias , ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome), renal failure , and DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation) . Metabolic derangements like hypocalcemia , hyperglycemia , and hyperlipidemia may occur. Peripancreatic fluid collection , pancreatic abscess , pseudocyst , and pancreatic necrosis . Pleural effusion , pancreatic ascites , and pancreatic haemorrhage (pseudoaneurysm) are also common. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1272-1274

questions.question: Which of the following is not a risk factor for gallbladder cancer?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Polyp <10 mm Explanation: Gallbladder polyps smaller than 10 mm are generally not considered a significant risk factor for gallbladder cancer, while other conditions like porcelain gallbladder, primary sclerosing cholangitis, and large gallstones are associated with an increased risk. Risk Factors For Carcinoma GB Gallstones : 90% of carcinoma cases are associated with gallstones. The risk of developing carcinoma in gallstone disease is 7-10 times higher than in the general population. Relative risk based on stone size: Less than 2 cm: Lower risk 2-3 cm: Relative risk of 2.5 More than 3 cm (Option D) : Relative risk of 10 or more Other Conditions : Choledochal cyst Anomalous pancreaticobiliary duct junction (20%) Gallbladder polyps (more than 1 cm in size, more than 3 in number, or adenomatous polyps) Porcelain gallbladder (Option A): 25% risk of malignant transformation, with 90% being inoperable tumours Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (Option B) Infections and Inflammatory Conditions : Chronic typhoid carriers Inflammatory bowel disease Hepatitis B and hepatitis C virus infections Other factors: Polypoid lesions (GB polyp) Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis Nitrosamines Carcinogens Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1258 SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 651

questions.question: Which classification system is used for bile duct injury, taking location, injury to the duct, and vessel involvement into account?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Hannover Explanation: The Hannover classification is a comprehensive system for bile duct injuries , particularly post-cholecystectomy, that accounts for: Location of injury Type of duct injury (partial or complete) Presence of vascular injury (e.g., to the right hepatic artery) It provides a more detailed description compared to older systems and is especially useful in surgical planning. Type A : Cystic duct or gallbladder bed leak. Type B : Incomplete or complete stenosis. Type C : Lateral tangential injuries. Type D : Complete bile duct injury with vascular injuries. Type E : Late bile duct stenosis. Bismuth Classification: (Option A) Describes strictures of the biliary system , particularly benign biliary strictures after surgery. It is based solely on the location of the stricture relative to the hepatic duct confluence. Bismuth classification for biliary strictures Type I Common hepatic duct stump >2cm Stricture is Low Type II Common hepatic duct stump <2cm Stricture is mid Type III Hilar stricture with intact confluence Stricture is high Type IV Hilar stricture with destroyed confluence Type V Stricture involving aberrant right sectoral duct with or without stricture of common hepatic duct Strasberg classification (Option B) divides bile duct injuries into five main classes: Type A (M/C) Cystic duct stump leak or leak from sub-vesical duct of Luschka Type B Ligation or occlusion of aberrant right sectoral duct Type C Transection without occlusion of the aberrant right sectoral duct Type D Injury to the lateral wall of the Common hepatic duct Type E E1 to E5 Bismuth classification Stewart-Way Classification (Option C): Focuses on mechanisms of injury and surgeon-related errors , useful for root cause analysis rather than guiding surgical repair. Stewart-Way Classification: Class I : Incomplete injury. Class II : Lateral injury with bile leak and stenosis. Class III : Complete transection of the common bile duct (most common, 60%). Class IV : Duct branch injuries with involvement of the right hepatic artery.

questions.question: A patient underwent cholecystectomy, and the histopathology reveals carcinoma with invasion into the muscular layer. What is the next best step?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Extended Cholecystectomy Explanation: T1b lesions refer to gallbladder cancer that invades the muscular layer but not beyond the deeper layers. The next best step is extended cholecystectomy to ensure an R0 resection , which includes removal of the surrounding lymph nodes (e.g., hepatoduodenal, gastrohepatic) and possibly part of the hepatic parenchyma to achieve clear margins. TNM Staging of Gall bladder Carcinoma: Category Description Tis Carcinoma in situ T1 Tumor invades lamina propria or muscle layer T1a Tumor invades lamina propria T1b Tumor invades muscle layer T2 Tumor invades perimuscular connective tissue T2a Tumor does not extend to serosa T2b Tumor extends to serosa, but does not invade the liver T3 Tumor perforates serosa and/or invades liver/adjacent organs T4 Tumor invades main portal vein/hepatic artery/multiple extrahepatic organs Lymph node N0 No regional lymph node metastasis N1 Metastases to 1-3 regional lymph nodes N2 Metastases to >3 regional lymph nodes Metastasis M0 No distant metastasis M1 Distant metastasis Gallbladder Cancer Treatment: Gallbladder Polyp: Adenomatous polyps have malignant potential. Risk factors for malignancy: Single polyp, size >1 cm, age >50 years. Management: Cholecystectomy is recommended for polyps >1 cm. Polyps <1 cm may undergo surveillance, except in PSC (where earlier cholecystectomy is advised).
