Gallbladder Cancer Post-Cholecystectomy: T1a Lesions (mucosa, lamina propria): Cholecystectomy T1b Lesions (muscular invasion) : Extended cholecystectomy is recommended, especially with vascular, perineural, or lymphatic invasion. T2 Lesions (past muscularis): Radical cholecystectomy with lymph node removal as more than 40% have nodal metastasis. T3/T4 Lesions (extensive): Extended surgery, including liver resection, may be needed for R0 margins. Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 1518,1519

questions.question: Which of the following statements about Choledochal Cyst is incorrect?

options.B: The cyst can be opened directly and drained
options.C: Todani classification is used for grading

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) The cyst can be opened directly and drained Explanation: Choledochal cysts should not be simply drained. Direct drainage can lead to complications, including infection and further dilation. The proper treatment usually involves surgical resection of the cyst and reconstruction of the bile duct. Choledochal Cyst: Congenital dilatations of the intra- and/or extrahepatic biliary system can present at any age. In choledochal cysts, there is an abnormal junction between the bile duct and the pancreatic duct (Option D) , leading to the reflux of pancreatic enzymes into the common bile duct (CBD). The presence of these enzymes in the CBD causes its dilation. Clinical features : Patients may present with jaundice, fever, abdominal pain, and a right upper quadrant mass. Pancreatitis is a frequent presentation in adults. Approximately 60% of cases are diagnosed before the age of 10 years. The classical triad of jaundice, right upper quadrant mass, and abdominal pain is present in only a minority of patients (0–17%) Patients have an increased risk of developing malignancies like: Cholangiocarcinoma (Option A) Squamous cell carcinoma Bile duct sarcoma Hepatoma Pancreatic carcinoma Gallbladder carcinoma Todani modification of Alonso- Lej classification (Option C) Type I Ia Cystic dilation of the extrahepatic bile duct (Most common) Ib Focal segmental dilation of extrahepatic bile duct Ic Fusiform dilation of extrahepatic bile duct Type II Diverticular dilation of extrahepatic bile duct Type III Dilatation of intraduodenal part of bile duct (choledochocele) Type IV IV a Dilatation of both intra and extrahepatic bile duct IV b Multiple cysts involving extrahepatic bile duct only Type V Multiple cysts involving intrahepatic bile duct only (Caroli’s disease) Type Treatment Type I Complete excision, cholecystectomy, Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy Type II Complete excision Type III Transduodenal excision or sphincteroplasty, endoscopic drainage may suffice Type IVa Tailored to anatomy: extrahepatic cysts treated like Type I; partial hepatectomy and reconstruction for localised intrahepatic involvement Type IVb Managed like Type I Type V (Caroli disease) Resection for unilobar disease; liver transplantation for diffuse disease

questions.question: A 20-year-old male presents with acute epigastric pain and fever. He has a history of cholelithiasis. On examination, abdominal guarding and rigidity are noted. Laboratory results show elevated serum amylase and lipase levels, along with leukocytosis. What is the most likely diagnosis for his condition? B. III > 75 per cent of patients present with hypercalcemia

options.A: Serum amylase remains elevated even after 30 days of resolution of acute pancreatitis
options.C: Serum lipase is more specific than serum amylase
options.D: Increase in the level of serum lipase is directly proportional to the severity

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Serum lipase is more specific than serum amylase Explanation: The most likely diagnosis here is acute pancreatitis , given the acute epigastric pain, fever, history of cholelithiasis, abdominal guarding, rigidity, & elevated serum amylase and lipase levels along with leukocytosis. Serum lipase is indeed more specific than amylase for diagnosing acute pancreatitis. While both enzymes are elevated in pancreatitis, lipase tends to remain elevated longer and is more directly associated with pancreatic damage. (Option A ruled out) Serum amylase levels can also be elevated in other acute abdominal conditions such as perforation, volvulus, and torsion. If amylase remains elevated for more than a few weeks, it could indicate a chronic condition or other non-pancreatic diseases. > 75 per cent of patients present with hypercalcemia (Option B) : Hypercalcemia is not a common feature of acute pancreatitis. In fact, hypocalcemia is more commonly observed in acute pancreatitis, which happens due to the precipitation of calcium salts in the pancreatic tissue because of the saponification of fat. Increase in the level of serum lipase is directly proportional to the severity (Option D) : Lipase and amylase do not directly correlate with the severity of the disease, and n one of the commonly used scoring systems for grading pancreatitis directly rely on the values of amylase or lipase to assess the severity of the condition. Reference: SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Pages 675 - 680

questions.question: A 39-year-old patient presented with RTA and is brought to ER with a pulse rate of 120/min, and SBP of <80mmHg. Despite intravenous fluid resuscitation and BT, the patient's condition deteriorates with ongoing profuse bleeding from the liver . Identify the procedure shown in the image done to control massive liver bleed.
questions.explanation: hepatoduodenal ligament, which contains the portal vein, hepatic artery, and common bile duct. This maneuver is used to control bleeding from the liver by temporarily interrupting blood flow to the liver. It is a common technique used during liver surgery or to manage traumatic liver bleeding. Incorrect options: Option A - Kocher

questions.question: Which condition is most likely based on the image findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Choledocholithiasis Explanation: The MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography) image reveals dilation of the common bile duct (CBD) along with filling defects, representing gallstones within the duct. Filling defects on MRCP indicate an obstruction in the bile ducts, commonly caused by gallstones (choledocholithiasis) or other blockages. These defects appear as areas where the bile duct does not fill properly or has reduced signal intensity. Symptoms of choledocholithiasis typically include jaundice, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Treatment often involves endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with sphincterotomy and stone extraction. Incorrect Options: Stricture (Option A) : A bile duct stricture appears as narrowing or constriction of the bile duct caused by inflammation, scarring, or tumours obstructing the duct. While it can mimic choledocholithiasis on imaging, it does not show the characteristic filling defects seen in choledocholithiasis. Cholecystitis (Option C) is the inflammation of the gallbladder, usually due to gallstones blocking the cystic duct. MRCP typically shows gallbladder wall thickening, pericholecystic fluid, and gallstones in the gallbladder but not changes in the bile ducts, so it wouldn't cause CBD dilation or filling defects. Cholangiocarcinoma (Option D) is a malignant tumour of the bile duct epithelium. On MRCP, it can cause bile duct dilation and strictures and may also show intraductal masses or nodules. However, the pattern of obstruction caused by a tumour differs from the filling defects seen with choledocholithiasis, as these defects are caused by gallstones, not a mass.

questions.question: What is the sign of the gallbladder seen in this USG?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Phrygian cap sign Explanation: The image on the ultrasound (USG) shows the Phrygian cap sign , which is a common anatomical variation of the gallbladder. A Phrygian cap is a congenital variant of the gallbladder characterised by a fold at the fundus that resembles a cap. It is a benign condition and is typically asymptomatic, with its appearance being consistent with a cap-like structure on ultrasound. It has no pathological significance and does not affect gallbladder function. Incorrect Options: Murphy sign (Option B) is a clinical finding seen in acute cholecystitis, where pain and inspiratory arrest occur upon palpation of the gallbladder. It is not related to the anatomical variation seen in the USG image. Claw sign (Option C) is a radiological feature seen in intussusception , not related to the gallbladder. Omega sign (Option D) is a radiological finding observed in choledochal cysts , where the dilated common bile duct forms an "omega" or "figure-of-8" shape. It does not relate to the anomaly shown in the USG image.

questions.question: After laparoscopic cholecystectomy, what should the expected urine output be in a patient with normal renal function?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 0.5-1.5 ml/kg/min Explanation: The normal urine output is around 1500 ml/day for a healthy adult, which roughly translates to 0.5-1.5 ml/kg/hour . (1x70(kg)x24(hours) ~ 1700 ml). Minimum urine output to excrete end products of protein metabolism: 500ml/day Ideal urine output in a normal 70kg adult: 1500 ml Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 792

questions.question: A 35-year-old patient with a history of dysentery for 6 weeks complains of pain in the right upper abdomen. On ultrasound, a hypoechoic hyperdense lesion is seen in the liver. Based on the given image, identify the condition.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Amoebic liver abscess Explanation: The ultrasound image shows a hypoechoic hyperdense lesion in the liver. Given the patient's clinical history of dysentery, the most likely diagnosis is an amoebic liver abscess . Amoebic liver abscess is caused by the protozoan parasite Entamoeba histolytica , typically contracted through the ingestion of contaminated food or water. On ultrasound, the abscess appears as a well-defined, hypoechoic lesion with variable internal echoes . Mild to moderate oedema in the surrounding liver parenchyma may also be seen. Feature Amebic Abscess Pyogenic Abscess Age 20–40 years >50 years Male-to-Female Ratio ≥ 10:1 1.5:1 Solitary vs Multiple Solitary 80% Solitary 50% Location Usually right liver Usually right liver Travel in Endemic Area Yes No Diabetes Uncommon ( ∼ 2%) More common ( ∼ 27%) Alcohol Use Common Common Jaundice Uncommon Common Elevated Bilirubin Uncommon Common Elevated Alkaline Phosphatase Common Common Positive Blood Culture No Common Positive Amebic Serology Yes No Incorrect Options: Pyogenic liver abscess (Option B) : A pyogenic liver abscess, caused by bacterial infections like Escherichia coli or Klebsiella pneumoniae , usually presents as multiple hypoechoic lesions on ultrasound, rather than the single lesion shown here. Inflammation in the surrounding liver parenchyma may also be evident. Hydatid cyst (Option C) : Caused by the larval stage of Echinococcus granulosus , hydatid cysts typically appear as well-defined, anechoic, or hypoechoic lesions, often with multiple daughter cysts inside. The provided image shows a single hypoechoic hyperdense lesion, which is inconsistent with a hydatid cyst. Hemangioma (Option D) :

questions.question: A patient presents with fever, abdominal pain, and jaundice. Investigations show the given findings. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

options.C: Angioembolization is the treatment of choice
options.D: Echinococcus species is involved in etiology

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Echinococcus species is involved in etiology Explanation: The patient's symptoms of fever, abdominal pain, and jaundice, along with the provided findings of a serpentine linear membrane (a wavy membrane within the cyst), suggest a diagnosis of hydatid disease or echinococcosis . This condition is caused by infection with the Echinococcus species of tapeworm, typically transmitted through contact with dogs or livestock. Hydatid disease: Caused by Echinococcus granulosus (dog tapeworm). Humans are intermediate hosts, infected through oral ingestion of eggs from dogs. Clinical features: Common organs affected : Liver (most common), lungs, brain. Symptoms: Abdominal pain, jaundice, dysphagia, dyspnea, neurological signs (headache, ICP). It can present after trauma or with anaphylactic shock. Diagnosis: Eosinophilia , positive serology (ELISA, immunoelectrophoresis). Imaging : Ultrasound, CT, MRCP (for biliary involvement). Treatment: PAIR technique (Puncture, Aspiration, Injection, Reaspiration) after albendazole or praziquantel. Radical pericystectomy or segmentectomy for hepatic cases. Omentoplasty or laparoscopic marsupialization for cysts. Scolicidal agents : Hypertonic saline, ethanol, or povidone-iodine used during surgery. Laparoscopic marsupialization (deroofing) for cysts. Cyst aspiration, followed by scolicidal agent application and sealing biliary communications. Surgery is mandatory (Option A) : While surgery is often an effective treatment for hydatid cysts, it is not always required. In some cases, non-surgical options such as antiparasitic medications or percutaneous drainage may be more suitable. Fine-needle aspiration cytology is diagnostic (Option B) : Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) is generally avoided in the diagnosis of echinococcosis due to the risk of triggering anaphylaxis and the potential to spread the infection. Angioembolization is the treatment of choice (Option C) : Angioembolization is not typically the first-line treatment for hydatid disease and is not commonly used as a

questions.question: A 55-year-old alcoholic patient presents with sudden and unintentional weight loss. Lab investigations revealed serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) of 240 IU/L, alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) of 600 ng/ml, and normal serum AST and ALT levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Hepatocellular carcinoma Explanation: The patient's normal AST and ALT, along with the raised ALP, are consistent with cholestasis or hepatic malignancy. Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is a primary liver cancer often seen in patients with chronic liver disease, including those with alcoholism. The elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is a marker commonly associated with HCC. Hepatocellular carcinoma: Tumor Markers: Elevated Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels above 20 ng/ml are observed in approximately 70% of cases of hepatocellular carcinoma. An increase in PIVKA-II (Protein Induced by Vitamin K Absence or Antagonism-II) is also noted. Diagnosis: The initial diagnostic test for suspected Hepatocellular carcinoma is an ultrasound (USG). The preferred method for definitive diagnosis of HCC is a Triple Phase CT scan , which highlights arterial hypervascularization and venous washout. A triple-phase CT scan has the following phases: Arterial Phase - HCC shows hyperenhancement due to its arterial blood supply. Portal Venous Phase - HCC may appear isodense or hypodense as it becomes less conspicuous compared to the surrounding liver tissue. Delayed Phase - HCC exhibits washout, a characteristic feature - appearing hypodense relative to the liver parenchyma. Quadriphasic images of the enhancement features in a typical large HCC (arrows) demonstrating hypo-attenuation on non-contrast (NC)-enhanced phase, mosaic hyperenhancement on arterial phase (AP) and washout on portal venous phase (PVP) and delayed phase (DP) For screening individuals at high risk, the recommended test is an ultrasound (USG) Risk factors for HCC: Cirrhosis Metabolic disorders Environmental factors HBV infection HCV infection Alcohol NAFLD Primary biliary cirrhosis Chronic active hepatitis Hemochromatosis Wilson's Disease Glycogen Storage Disorder α 1AT-deficiency Porphyria cutanea tarda Citrullinemia Orotic aciduria Alagille's syndrome Cigarette Smoking Anabolic steroids Aflatoxin Thorotrast

questions.question: A patient presents with features of chronic pancreatitis, including recurrent attacks, and has a 10 mm dilatation of the pancreatic duct with intraductal calculi present. Which of the following is the surgery of choice?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy Explanation: In chronic pancreatitis with dilated pancreatic ducts and intraductal stones, a longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy is commonly performed to relieve obstruction and drain the pancreatic duct. This procedure is effective in managing pain and improving pancreatic function. Treatment of Chronic Pancreatitis: Medical Management: Most patients with chronic pancreatitis can be managed with medical measures. There is no single therapeutic agent proven to relieve all symptoms. The primary goals are to manage pain, prevent complications, and address nutritional issues. Medical approaches include: Treating the Addiction Pain relief Nutritional Support and Pharmacological Measures: Diet: Low in fat, high in protein and carbohydrates. Pancreatic Enzyme Supplementation with meals to aid digestion. Micronutrient Therapy: Correct malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, and K) and vitamin B12, and provide supplements like methionine, vitamins C and E, and selenium, which may reduce pain and slow disease progression. Reducing gastric secretions may help some patients. Diabetes Management may be required if pancreatic damage leads to endocrine dysfunction. Surgical interventions: Pancreatic Sphincterotomy: May benefit patients with papillary stenosis or elevated pancreatic ductal pressure. Stent Placement: For patients with dominant pancreatic duct strictures and upstream dilatation. Stents should be removed after 4-6 weeks to prevent blockage. Pancreaticoduodenectomy or Beger Procedure (duodenum-preserving pancreatic head resection) is recommended for mass lesions in the pancreatic head. Longitudinal Pancreatojejunostomy or Frey Procedure : For markedly dilated ducts to provide pain relief, especially in cases where the disease affects the pancreatic duct. Distal Pancreatectomy: May be curative in patients with disease limited to the tail of the pancreas. Total Pancreatectomy: For intractable pain and diffuse disease, though it significantly impacts pancreatic function and quality of life. The pain relief success rate is approximately 33%, with a high risk of mortality and complications. Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Option A) is a major surgical procedure, also known as the Whipple procedure, typically reserved for pancreatic head tumours. It is not usually the first-line treatment for chronic pancreatitis with intraductal calculi. ERCP and Sphincterotomy (Option C): This endoscopic procedure is effective in treating certain cases of chronic pancreatitis, especially when there is a dominant stricture or obstruction in the pancreatic duct. However, when there is significant ductal dilation and the presence of large stones, surgical options tend to be more effective than endoscopic treatment. Coring of Pancreas Head (Frey’s Procedure) (Option D): This procedure, commonly used in patients with chronic pancreatitis affecting the head of the pancreas, involves the removal of the diseased tissue. It is not the first-choice intervention in cases with a markedly dilated duct and intraductal calculi. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1279,1280

questions.question: A patient arrives with pain in the right upper abdomen. One week ago, the patient experienced a bout of diarrhoea. Abdominal CT scan results indicate the presence of a liver abscess measuring approximately 25 cubic centimetres. What should be the subsequent course of action in treating this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Medical therapy Explanation: The initial treatment for a liver abscess typically involves medical therapy with broad-spectrum antibiotics. Percutaneous drainage or PAIR may be considered if the abscess does not improve with antibiotics or if it grows in size or becomes symptomatic. Surgery is reserved for more complicated or non-drainable abscesses. Management of Hepatic Pyogenic Abscess: Initial Management: Broad-Spectrum Antibiotics: Start immediately to control bacteremia and prevent complications. Antibiotics should cover gram-negative, gram-positive, and anaerobic organisms (e.g., ampicillin, aminoglycoside, metronidazole). Typically 2 weeks or more, depending on infection resolution and drainage success. Drainage Techniques: Percutaneous Drainage: First-line treatment with success rates of 66% to 90% . Advantages: Simpler, avoids general anaesthesia. Contraindications: Ascites, coagulopathy, proximity to vital structures. Percutaneous drainage should be attempted first, reserving surgery for failures. Percutaneous Aspiration: Less effective than percutaneous catheter drainage but reasonable for initial treatment. Surgical drainage: Reserved for cases where percutaneous drainage fails or when surgery is needed for underlying conditions (e.g., appendicitis). Feature Amebic Abscess Pyogenic Abscess Age 20–40 years >50 years Male-to-Female Ratio ≥ 10:1 1.5:1 Solitary vs Multiple Solitary 80% Solitary 50% Location Usually right liver Usually right liver Travel in Endemic Area Yes No Diabetes Uncommon ( ∼ 2%) More common ( ∼ 27%) Alcohol Use Common Common Jaundice Uncommon Common Elevated Bilirubin Uncommon Common Elevated Alkaline Phosphatase Common Common Positive Blood Culture No Common Positive Amebic Serology Yes No Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 1455,1459

questions.question: Which of the following is the best preferred investigation for Neuroendocrine Tumors (NETs)?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) PET Explanation: The investigation of choice for the localization of Pancreatic Neuroendocrine Tumors (PNETs) is SRS (somatostatin receptor scintigraphy). They are derived from pleuripotent stem cells. Classified as functional and non-functional PNETs Subtypes: Insulinoma (most common functional PNET) Gastrinoma (most common functional and malignant PNET) Non-functional tumors VIPoma Glucagonoma Somatostatinoma Carcinoid ACTHoma GRFoma It is symptomatic and diagnosed at an early stage. Diagnosis: Laboratory measurement of active substances or its by products. PET (Positron Emission Tomography)/CT: Preferred investigation for NETs nowadays. (Option D) Tracer: 68Gallium (68Ga)-labeled somatostatin analogs Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (SRS) is used for the localization of NETs. (IOC). All Neuroendocrine tumors express Somatostatin receptors except Insulinoma. It is not used nowadays. (Option B ruled out) USG (ultrasound) (Option A) is not the best choice for pancreatic NETs because the pancreas is deep in the abdomen, making it hard to visualize. It is useful for detecting large masses but is less sensitive for smaller tumors or those without distinct features. MRI (Option C) is useful for pancreatic tumors and liver metastases but lacks the functional detail of SRS. SRS is the gold standard for detecting somatostatin receptor-positive NETs. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 905. Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 634. PET/CT imaging of neuroendocrine tumors with 68Gallium-labeled somatostatin analogues: An overview and single institutional experience from India

questions.question: A chronic-alcoholic presents to the emergency room with acute pain in the abdomen in the epigastric region radiating to the back with nausea, anorexia, and occasional vomiting. Investigations showed elevated amylase levels (3 times) and total count. Likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Acute pancreatitis Explanation: The scenario of a chronic alcoholic presenting with epigastric abdominal pain radiating to the back, along with nausea, anorexia, occasional vomiting, and elevated amylase levels and total count, is indicative of Acute Pancreatitis. Clinical Diagnosis (Requires 2 of 3): Abdominal pain is strongly suggestive of acute pancreatitis. (Option B) Serum amylase and/or lipase (more specific) level at least 3 times the upper limit of normal. (Option B) Imaging findings characteristic of acute pancreatitis. X-ray Features Sentinel loop sign : Dilated loop of small intestine near the inflamed pancreas due to localized ileus. Significance : Early indicator of acute pancreatitis on X-ray. Sentinel loop sign Colon cut-off sign : Abrupt termination of gas in the colon at the splenic flexure, with collapsed distal colon loops. Significance : Suggests localized pancreatic inflammation, causing colonic spasm as an indirect sign of acute pancreatitis Investigations of Choice: Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) : Primary tool for assessing pancreatic necrosis, peripancreatic inflammation, fluid collections, and complications. Most reliable for staging and detecting complications. May underestimate necrosis if done in the first 24 hours. Morphological Types (Revised Atlanta Classification 2008): Interstitial oedematous pancreatitis : Mild form with pancreatic oedema and swelling but no necrosis. Necrotising pancreatitis: Severe form involving pancreatic parenchymal necrosis, associated with higher morbidity and mortality. Acute hepatitis (Option A) is liver inflammation, often caused by viral infections, alcohol, or toxins, with symptoms like jaundice, fatigue, dark urine, and elevated liver enzymes (ALT, AST). This diagnosis is unlikely for the patient, as her symptoms of epigastric pain, elevated amylase, and the absence of jaundice or liver enzyme elevation point more toward pancreatitis. Acute Cholecystitis (Option C) , caused by gallstones, presents with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and nausea, with ultrasound showing gallstones or thickened walls. However, the patient's epigastric pain and elevated amylase suggest pancreatitis, not cholecystitis. Acute appendicitis (Option D) presents with right lower quadrant pain, fever, elevated white blood cell count, and pain that starts around the umbilicus, shifting to the lower right abdomen. In this case, the patient has epigastric pain and elevated amylase, making appendicitis unlikely, as it doesn’t typically affect amylase levels.

questions.question: A 50-year-old alcoholic patient presents with a history of waxing and waning jaundice for the past 2 months. His CT examination reveals dilatation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct. What is the most probable diagnosis in the patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Periampullary carcinoma Explanation: The scenario of an alcoholic patient experiencing fluctuating jaundice, with a CT scan showing dilation of both the common bile duct and pancreatic duct, is most likely indicative of Periampullary Carcinoma . It originates in the pancreas, bile duct, or intestines close to the ampulla of Vater (the region where the common bile duct and pancreatic duct converge and enter the duodenum). They can cause obstruction of both the common bile duct and pancreatic duct. Clinical features: Jaundice (waxing and waning) (most common) A palpable, non-tender gallbladder Weight loss Abdominal pain Nausea/vomiting Pruritus Fever Gastrointestinal bleeding Cholangiocarcinoma (Option A) arises from the bile ducts and can cause common bile duct dilatation. However, the waxing and waning jaundice and dilatation of the pancreatic duct, in this case, are more indicative of periampullary carcinoma. Cholangiocarcinoma usually presents with more progressive jaundice. Common bile duct stone (Option C) can cause ductal dilatation, but the waxing and waning jaundice and pancreatic duct involvement make periampullary carcinoma more likely. Bile duct stones typically cause acute, not fluctuating, jaundice. Head of the pancreas carcinoma (Option D) can cause ductal dilatation, but periampullary carcinoma is a more specific diagnosis given the involvement of both the common bile duct and pancreatic duct. Pancreatic cancer typically presents with continuous jaundice, not fluctuating. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1244. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 1553-1555.

questions.question: What is the most effective technique for procuring tissue for the purpose of diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma?

options.A: Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound

questions.explanation: aspiration cytology (FNAC) guided by endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is considered the best method to obtain tissue for the diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma. E US allows for precise visualization and targeting of the pancreatic lesion, while FNAC involves using a thin needle to extract cells for examination under a microscope. This method is minimally invasive, has high diagnostic accuracy, and can provide valuable information for staging and treatment planning. Incorrect Options: Option B - MRI-guided biopsy: While MRI can provide detailed images of pancreatic tumors, it is not typically used for biopsy procedures. MRI-guided biopsies are not commonly performed for pancreatic carcinoma diagnosis. Option C - Laparoscopic-guided biopsy: Laparoscopic-guided biopsies may be considered in some cases, but they are generally not the first-line approach for obtaining tissue for the diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma. Laparoscopic procedures involve making small incisions and using a camera and surgical instruments to access and visualize the pancreas. However, transgastric FNAC guided by EUS is preferred over laparoscopic-guided biopsies due to its minimally invasive nature. Option D - Percutaneous transperitoneal biopsy: Percutaneous transperitoneal biopsies involve inserting a needle through the abdominal wall to reach the pancreas and obtain tissue samples. While this method may be used in some cases, it is generally less preferred compared to transgastric FNAC guided by EUS, which provides better visualization and targeting of the pancreatic lesion. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: For which of the following conditions is AFP a tumor marker?
questions.explanation: marker. Hepatocellular Carcinoma is the most common type of primary liver cancer, and AFP is one of the key tumor markers associated with this disease. AFP is a protein the liver produces during fetal development, and its levels decrease after birth. However, in certain conditions, such as HCC, the production of AFP can be reactivated, leading to elevated levels in the blood. Measuring AFP levels in the blood can be helpful in screening, diagnosing, and monitoring the progression of HCC. High levels of AFP are often seen in patients with HCC, although it is important to note that not all individuals with HCC will have elevated AFP levels. Elevated AFP levels can also be seen in other conditions such as cirrhosis, hepatitis, and certain germ cell tumors. Incorrect Options: Option B - RCC: ESR, CEA, haptoglobin, fibrinogen, and C3 to estimate the staging of RCC and ESR, CEA, haptoglobin, and C3 to estimate the prognosis. Option C - Oncocytoma: Oncocytomas are benign tumors commonly found in the kidneys but can also occur in other organs, such as the salivary glands, thyroid, and parathyroid glands. Unlike malignant tumors, oncocytomas do not typically produce specific tumor markers commonly associated with cancer. Option D - Chordoma: Chordomas are rare, slow-growing malignant tumors that arise from remnants of the notochord, a structure present during early embryonic development. They usually occur in the skull base, spine, or sacrum bones. Unlike many other cancers, chordomas do not typically produce specific tumor markers widely used for diagnostic or monitoring purposes. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following cancers rarely metastasizes to the liver ?
questions.explanation: pelvis, and long bones. Liver metastasis is relatively rare in prostate cancer compared to other sites. Incorrect Options: Option A - Colon: Colon cancer commonly metastasizes to the liver. The liver is a common site of metastasis for colorectal cancer, and liver metastases are often seen in advanced stages of the disease. Option B - Breast: Breast cancer can metastasize to various organs, including the liver. Liver metastases from breast cancer are relatively common, especially in the advanced stages of the disease. Option D - Melanoma: Melanoma, a type of skin cancer, has the potential to spread to various organs, including the liver. Liver metastases from melanoma can occur, although they are less common than metastases to the lymph nodes, lungs, or brain. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: A 43-year-old female presents to the clinic with a complaint of recurrent right upper quadrant pain complaint. They exacerbate, especially after eating. An ultrasound of the abdomen is performed, which comes out to be non-conclusive. Which of the following procedures is indicated in the image below?
questions.explanation: suggests the procedure of endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP). ERCP is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure used to evaluate and treat disorders of the bile ducts and pancreatic ducts. It involves the use of an endoscope, a flexible tube with a light and camera, which is inserted through the mouth and guided down to the duodenum. Contrast dye is then injected into the bile ducts or pancreatic ducts, and X-ray images are taken to visualize the anatomy and detect any abnormalities. In the given clinical scenario, the patient is experiencing recurrent right upper quadrant pain, which can be indicative of biliary system pathology. The non-conclusive ultrasound abdomen suggests the need for further evaluation of the bile ducts. ERCP allows direct visualization of the bile ducts and can help identify any obstructions, strictures, or other abnormalities that may be causing the patient's symptoms. It can also be used for therapeutic interventions, such as removing gallstones or placing stents to relieve obstructions. Incorrect Options: Option A - Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram: This involves the

questions.question: A chronic alcoholic patient came to the emergency with pain in the epigastrium radiating to the back and recurrent vomiting . On examination, guarding was present in the upper epigastrium . The erect chest X-ray was normal. What is the next step?
questions.explanation: Measuring serum lipase levels can help confirm the diagnosis and guide further management. Elevated lipase levels, along with the patient's clinical presentation, would support the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis. Incorrect Option: Option A - Upper GI endoscopy: Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy is not the immediate next step in this scenario because the patient's symptoms and examination findings suggest pancreatitis rather than an upper gastrointestinal pathology. Pancreatitis should be considered and investigated first. Option B - Alcohol breath test: An alcohol breath test may be useful in determining recent alcohol consumption. While chronic alcoholism is a risk factor for pancreatitis, a breath test alone would not confirm the diagnosis or guide immediate management. Therefore, the next step in this situation is not the most appropriate one. Option D - CECT: Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) scan is a valuable diagnostic tool for assessing pancreatic pathology, including pancreatitis. However, in this scenario, the patient's clinical presentation and examination findings strongly suggest acute pancreatitis. Given the typical clinical picture, a serum lipase test would be the more appropriate and efficient next step before considering more invasive imaging studies. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: The most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas is:
questions.explanation: pancreas. They arise from insulin-producing cells in the pancreas called beta cells. Insulinomas typically produce excessive amounts of insulin, leading to recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia (low blood sugar). They are usually benign and solitary tumors. Incorrect Options: Option A - Gastrinoma: Gastrinomas are neuroendocrine tumors that occur in the duodenum or pancreas. They produce excessive amounts of gastrin, leading to a condition called Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. Gastrinomas are typically associated with peptic ulcers and acid hypersecretion rather than being the most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas. Option B - Somatostatinoma: Somatostatinomas are rare neuroendocrine tumors that can arise in various organs, including the pancreas. These tumors produce excessive amounts of somatostatin, which inhibits the release of multiple hormones. While somatostatinomas can occur in the pancreas, they are relatively rare compared to other neuroendocrine tumors. Option D - VIPoma: VIPomas, also known as Verner-Morrison syndrome or pancreatic cholera, are neuroendocrine tumors that secrete vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP). These tumors are rare and can occur in the pancreas or other organs. VIPoma is associated with a condition called VIPoma syndrome, which includes symptoms such as severe diarrhea, dehydration, electrolyte imbalances, and flushing. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: What is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis ?
questions.explanation: TIGARO Classification of Etiology: T - Toxic - Metabolic I - Idiopathic G - Genetic A - Autoimmune R - Recurrent severe O - Obstructive Incorrect Options: Option A - Gallstones: Gallstones can cause acute pancreatitis when they obstruct the pancreatic duct, leading to inflammation. However, while gallstones can contribute to recurrent acute pancreatitis, they are not the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis. Option C - Autoimmune: Autoimmune pancreatitis is a relatively rare condition characterized by chronic inflammation of the pancreas due to an autoimmune reaction. It is an important cause of chronic pancreatitis, but it is less common than alcohol-induced pancreatitis. Option D - Drugs: Certain medications, such as certain antiretroviral drugs used in HIV/AIDS treatment or certain immunosuppressive drugs used in organ transplant recipients, can rarely cause chronic pancreatitis. However, drug-induced pancreatitis accounts for a small percentage of cases and is not the most common cause. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: What triad is characterized by abdominal pain, fever, and jaundice ?
questions.explanation: fever, and jaundice, the triad commonly associated with these symptoms is Charcot's triad . Charcot's triad is indicative of a condition affecting the biliary system, such as obstruction of the bile ducts due to gallstones or other causes. Charcot's Triad: Charcot's triad is a clinical term used to describe a combination of symptoms associated with acute cholangitis, which is inflammation of the bile ducts . The classic triad consists of: Abdominal pain : Typically located in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, it can be severe and colicky in nature. Fever: Often accompanied by chills and rigors. Jaundice: Yellowing of the skin and eyes due to elevated levels of bilirubin in the bloodstream. Incorrect Options: Option A - Saint Triad: Saint's triad comprises the simultaneous occurrence of the following medical conditions: gallstones (cholelithiasis), hiatal hernia, and diverticular disease (diverticulosis of the colon). Option C - Virchow Triad: The Virchow triad consists of blood stasis, endothelial injury, and hypercoagulability. Option D - Reynold's Pentad: Reynold's pentad is characterized by Charcot's triad alongside shock and alterations in mental status. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: In a 32-year-old male, who complained of fever and pain in the upper right abdomen following meals, the recommended diagnostic test is
questions.explanation: after food intake, the probable diagnosis is cholecystitis or gallstones. Cholecystitis refers to inflammation of the gallbladder, which is commonly caused by gallstones obstructing the cystic duct. The symptoms are often precipitated or worsened by food intake, particularly fatty meals. USG is the initial investigation of choice for evaluating the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, including the liver, gallbladder, and biliary system. USG is non-invasive, widely available, cost-effective, and does not involve exposure to ionizing radiation. Incorrect Options: Option A - CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography): While CECT can provide detailed imaging of the abdominal organs, it is not the investigation of choice as the initial step in this scenario. USG is preferred as it is a safer and more readily available option for evaluating gallbladder and biliary pathology. Option C - MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): MRI can provide detailed imaging of the abdominal organs without radiation exposure, but it is usually not the initial investigation for suspected cholecystitis or gallstones. MRI may be reserved for specific indications or if further characterization of the findings from USG is required. Option D - HRCT (High-Resolution Computed Tomography): HRCT is primarily used for evaluating lung parenchymal and interstitial lung diseases. It is not the investigation of choice for assessing the gallbladder or biliary system in this scenario. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: A 40-year-old man is brought to the casualty with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back for the past 1 day and has had 3 episodes of vomiting. The pain radiates to the back and is slightly relieved in the sitting forward position . The following signs are seen on examination and lab investigations reveal elevated lipase and amylase . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: with bruising in the subcutaneous fatty tissue around the peri-umbilical region, as well as the Grey Turner sign, which is flank ecchymosis. These signs are indicative of acute pancreatitis. Acute pancreatitis is characterized by pain in the abdomen that radiates to the back and is relieved in the sitting forward position. Elevated lipase and amylase are seen in acute pancreatitis. Incorrect Options: Option A, B and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of correct answer.

questions.question: What is the optimal management approach for a patient presenting with fever and abdominal pain five days after experiencing a common bile duct injury resulting in a leak ?
questions.explanation: with stenting is the optimal management approach for a patient presenting with fever and abdominal pain five days after experiencing a common bile duct injury resulting in a leak. ERCP : This procedure allows direct visualization of the bile ducts and enables interventions such as stent placement to address the bile duct injury. ERCP is a minimally invasive procedure performed by passing an endoscope through the mouth, esophagus, and stomach into the duodenum to access the bile ducts. Stenting : Stents are inserted during ERCP to facilitate bile drainage and promote healing of the bile duct injury. They also help maintain the patency of the duct and prevent further complications such as bile leakage and bile peritonitis. Incorrect Options: Option A - Ultrasound-guided aspiration: While ultrasound-guided aspiration may be useful for draining a biloma (collection of bile outside the biliary system), it does not address the underlying bile duct injury. Therefore, it is not the definitive management approach for this condition. Option C - Re-exploration and hepaticojejunostomy: Re-exploration and hepaticojejunostomy involve surgical intervention to repair the bile duct injury by creating a new connection between the bile duct and the jejunum. While this approach may be necessary in some cases, it is usually reserved for more complex or severe injuries. In the presented case, less invasive options such as ERCP with stenting are preferred before resorting to surgical intervention. Option D - Re-exploration and primary repair: Similar to option C, re-exploration and primary repair involve surgical intervention to directly repair the bile duct injury. This approach may be considered if less invasive options fail or if the injury is severe. However, it is not the initial management approach for a patient presenting with fever and abdominal pain after a common bile duct injury. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following represents a type III choledochal cyst from the given image ?
questions.explanation: biliary tree. These cysts can occur anywhere along the biliary tree, from the intrahepatic bile ducts to the common bile duct. Based on the location and extent of the dilation, choledochal cysts are classified into five types. Image C shows a Dilatation of the intraduodenal part of the bile duct (choledochocele); it represents a type III choledochal cyst. Incorrect Options: Option A - A: Type II cyst is Diverticular dilatation of the extrahepatic bile duct. Option B - B: Type I cyst is Cystic dilatation of extrahepatic bile duct (most common) Option D - D: Type V cyst involves multiple dilations of the intrahepatic and/or extrahepatic bile ducts. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas is commonly linked with necrolytic erythema migrans ?
questions.explanation: manifestation associated with glucagonoma, also known as the hyperglycemic cutaneous syndrome. NEM presents as a rash with erythema and necrosis, typically affecting the lower extremities and perineum. It's considered the most common symptom of glucagonoma. "4D" Syndrome: Glucagonoma is associated with a set of symptoms known as the "4D" syndrome: Diabetes Mellitus: Glucagonoma can lead to elevated blood glucose levels due to the excess release of glucagon, which opposes insulin action, contributing to the development of diabetes mellitus. Dermatitis: NEM, as described earlier, is the dermatological manifestation characterized by erythema and necrosis. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): Glucagonoma can increase the risk of DVT formation due to various factors such as hypercoagulability. Depression: Patients with glucagonoma may experience depression, which could be attributed to various physiological and psychological factors associated with the disease. Incorrect Options: Option A - Insulinoma: Insulinomas are neuroendocrine tumors of the pancreas that primarily secrete insulin. While hypoglycemia is a hallmark symptom of insulinoma due to excess insulin secretion, it is not associated with necrolytic erythema migrans. Option C - Somatostatinoma: Somatostatinomas are rare neuroendocrine tumors that overproduce somatostatin. Dermatological manifestations associated with somatostatinoma typically include acanthosis nigricans and diabetes mellitus, but not necrolytic erythema migrans. Option D - VIPoma: VIPomas are neuroendocrine tumors that secrete vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), leading to profuse watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria (WDHA syndrome). While VIPomas can lead to skin flushing, diarrhea is the prominent symptom, and necrolytic erythema migrans is not associated with VIPomas. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: What is the most likely diagnosis of the lesion shown in the image below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Neuropathic ulcer Explanation : The given image is suggestive of a neurogenic ulcer, which is a common type of ulcer seen in individuals with peripheral neuropathy and is often associated with diabetes or other conditions that cause nerve damage. The loss of sensation in the affected area leads to unawareness of trauma or pressure , making individuals more prone to developing these ulcers over time. Non-healing, painless, shallow, and punched-out appearance is characteristic of these ulcers and they commonly

questions.question: Which of the following findings is likely to be seen in this patient?

options.A: Decreased posterior tibial & dorasalis pedis pulsations
options.B: Loss of sensation over the foot
options.D: Pain on compression of the calf

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Loss of sensation over foot Explanation: The given image depicts a neurotrophic (diabetic) ulcer, where the loss of sensation in the foot is typically observed. Clinical features of different ulcers are as follows: Venous ulcer Arterial ulcer Neurotrophic ulcer Pressure ulcer Site Gaiter’s area (area between malleolus and calf) At distal ends of limbs, such as toes, feet and legs. Over toe joints, under the heel, over malleoli, under the metatarsal head, etc Seen over pressure points, most common are ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, hee, malleolus, occiput, etc Appearance Vertically oval with a sloping edge and will not penetrate deep fascia. Punched-out edges are seen in this type of ulcer. Ulcers can be associated with gangrene and abscesses; osteomyelitis can be seen here. Punched out ulcer with bone as a base. Cause Caused by ambulatory chronic venous hypertension due to varicose veins. This occurs due to severe arterial insufficiency of digital and medium-sized arteries, leading to ischemia and tissue death in the region. It is caused due to repeated trauma and ischemia due to microangiopathy in diabetic patients . It is tissue necrosis and ulceration due to prolonged pressure

questions.question: A 32-year-old male chronic smoker presents with pain in the fingers for a few months. On examination, gangrenous ulcers were present in the fingers, as shown below. Investigation showed blood glucose and lipid profile within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Feature Details Definition Non-atherosclerotic, segmental inflammatory vasculitis affecting small & medium-sized arteries and veins. Etiology Strong association with tobacco use (smoking or chewing). Exact cause unknown (likely immune-mediated). Epidemiology Young males (20–45 years), most commonly smokers. More common in Middle East, South Asia. Pathophysiology Inflammation leads to thrombosis and vascular occlusion. Sparing of proximal arteries (unlike atherosclerosis). Segmental involvement (skip lesions). Clinical Features Claudication, rest pain (foot, hands). Raynaud’s phenomenon (vasospasm causing colour changes in fingers/toes). Ulcers & gangrene (especially in fingers/toes). Migratory superficial thrombophlebitis (inflamed veins). Diagnosis Clinical diagnosis (no specific lab tests). Doppler & Angiography → Corkscrew collateral vessels (pathognomonic). Exclusion of other causes (diabetes, atherosclerosis, vasculitis). Management Complete smoking cessation (most important). Vasodilators (e.g., calcium channel blockers for Raynaud’s). Antiplatelets & anticoagulants (limited benefit). Pain management (NSAIDs, opioids if needed). Amputation (for non-healing ulcers or gangrene). Prognosis Poor if smoking continues but stabilises with smoking cessation. Diabetic ulcers (Option B) Occurs more commonly among patients(both males and females) with diabetes. It is seen more commonly in the foot. Acute paronychia (Option C) This is the most common infection of the hand. It is often caused by careless nail trimming or picking the skin around the nail fold. The pus is trapped beside the nail. Raynaud’s phenomenon (Option D) This phenomenon causes the blood vessels in the extremities to narrow, and it restricts the blood flow. This usually affects the fingers and toes. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1024, 1046

questions.question: What is the probable medical condition for an 80-year-old male who experienced pain and swelling in the calf muscle on the right side after being immobilized due to a fracture in the right inter-trochanteric region?
questions.explanation: Correct answer B) Deep vein thrombosis Explanation: The scenario of a patient being immobilised and exhibiting symptoms such as calf swelling and pain strongly indicate the likelihood of DVT. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) occurs when a blood clot forms in a deep vein, typically in the lower leg, thigh, or pelvis. Symptoms may include pain, swelling, and tenderness in the calf or thigh, along with warm and red skin. Virchow's Triad components - endothelial injury, stasis, and hypercoagulable state - increase the risk of DVT. Chronic osteomyelitis (Option A) The intraosseous blood vessels thrombose, and bone infarcts. Pus lifts the periosteum. To treat osteomyelitis, all dead tissue needs to be removed. If a fracture exists, it needs to be stabilized. Compartment syndrome (Option C) A compartment syndrome develops at any time during the first 48 hours after the accident or surgery. The patient usually complains of severe pain with some numbness in the foot. The foot may be cold still with pulses. Arterial claudication (Option D) Claudication is usually a symptom of peripheral artery disease, in which the arteries that supply blood, usually the legs, are narrowed. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1044. SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 217

questions.question: A 25-year-old male patient involved in a road traffic accident was managed upon arrival at the emergency room, with a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute and a blood pressure of 80/45mmHg, and exhibiting hyper-resonance on the left side of the chest, what is the appropriate action based on the findings from the chest x-ray?

options.A: Wide bore needle insertion in the 2nd ICS
options.B: Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS

questions.explanation: 5th ICS Correct answer B) Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS Explanation: The above condition indicates a tension pneumothorax. It is a life-threatening condition and should be immediately attended to. The appropriate management of a tension pneumothorax includes inserting a Wide-bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS along the axillary line, followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS to achieve decompression. Wide bore needle insertion in the 2nd ICS (Option A) The wide bore needle is to be inserted into the ICS 5th at the mid-clavicular line. Hence, this option is incorrect. Aspiration of the Pleural fluid (Option C) Aspiration of the pleural fluid is not done in case of a tension pneumothorax No intervention needed (Option D) A tension pneumothorax is a highly life-threatening condition and needs immediate intervention. Reference: Bailey and Love Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 374

questions.question: A patient underwent surgery, for which she was immobilised. Patient started complaining of leg pain on the 5th postoperative day. On examination , Homan’s sign is positive. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer A) Deep Venous thrombosis Explanation: Based on the information provided, the most probable diagnosis for the patient experiencing leg pain on the 5th postoperative day with a positive Homan's sign is Deep Venous Thrombosis (DVT). Homan's sign refers to calf pain elicited by dorsiflexion of the foot, and it is often associated with DVT. DVT is a condition in which a blood clot forms in a deep vein, commonly in the lower extremities. Immobilization following surgery is a known risk factor for the development of DVT. Other risk factors include a history of DVT, obesity, smoking, and certain medical conditions. Urinary sepsis (Option B) Urinary sepsis typically presents with symptoms such as fever, urinary urgency, and dysuria (painful urination), rather than leg pain. Peripheral vascular disease (Option C) Peripheral vascular disease refers to conditions that affect blood flow to the extremities and may cause pain or cramping during physical activity, but it is less likely to be related to the immobilization following surgery. Lymphangitis (Option D) Lymphangitis refers to the inflammation of lymphatic vessels, which can cause red streaks on the skin and swollen lymph nodes but is less likely to be associated with leg pain in this context. Clinical features of DVT : Clinical Feature Significance Localized tenderness Specific for DVT; indicates inflammation along the vein. Asymmetrical calf swelling Common but not specific to DVT. Erythema and warmth Suggestive of inflammation or thrombosis. Pain in the affected limb Can occur with or without movement; can indicate venous obstruction. Dilated superficial veins May indicate compensatory circulation due to deep venous obstruction. Homans' sign Non-specific; Passive forceful dorsiflexion of the foot with extended knee will cause tenderness in the calf. Mose’s sign Painful response to gentle squeezing of the lower calf from side-to-side. Neuhof's Sign Thickening and deep tenderness in the calf muscles upon palpation. Phlegmasia Alba Dolens DVT of the femoral vein causes painful congestion and edema of the leg with lymphangitis, which further increases edema (white leg). Phlegmasia Caerulea Dolens Extensive DVT in iliac and pelvic veins leading to a blue leg with possible venous gangrene or infarction. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1044. SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 217 Pratt sign

questions.question: How is empyema thoracis treated?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Chest tube drainage and antibiotics Explanation: Intercostal Chest Drainage (ICD) + IV Antibiotics is the standard treatment. Chest tube (ICD) removes pus, while broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., ceftriaxone + metronidazole or piperacillin-tazobactam) control infection.\ If loculated collections persist, intrapleural fibrinolytics (streptokinase, urokinase) may be needed . Antibiotics alone (Option A) Antibiotics are necessary but not sufficient because pus in the pleural cavity needs mechanical drainage . Without drainage, antibiotics cannot penetrate the thick fibrinous collections , leading to persistent infection. ICD alone (Option C) Drainage without antibiotics will not treat the underlying infection , leading to recurrence and sepsis . Wait and watch (Option D) Empyema needs urgent intervention . Delayed treatment can lead to fibrothorax (thickened pleura), lung entrapment, and sepsis . Reference: Thoracis empyema

questions.question: A man presented with a history of stab injury to the arm. On examination, there was a hematoma, and radial and ulnar pulses were not felt. A 3.5cm longitudinal tear is noted in the brachial artery. Which among the following is the best treatment option?

options.B: Repair with great saphenous vein graft

questions.explanation: pulses, indicating compromised blood flow to the arm's distal part. Urgent surgical intervention is crucial to restore blood flow and prevent ischemic complications. Using a great saphenous vein graft from the patient's lower extremity is a suitable option for arterial repair, facilitating reestablishment of blood flow and preservation of distal circulation. Primary repair with end-to-end anastomosis (Option A) Primary repair alone may not be feasible or successful in achieving adequate vessel approximation and blood flow restoration. Repair with prosthetic graft (Option C ) . Prosthetic grafts can be used for arterial repairs, they are typically reserved for larger vessels or when autologous vein grafts are not available or suitable. In this case, with a 3.5cm tear in the brachial artery, a prosthetic graft may not be the optimal choice. Repair with saphenous vein patch (Option D) : the tear in the brachial artery is longitudinal and 3.5cm in length, which may require a more substantial vascular reconstruction with a graft rather than a patch. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2813640/

questions.question: A 70-year-old female patient presents with pain in the thigh during walking. Investigation reveals the following finding as given below. What will be the best surgical management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Aortofemoral bypass Explanation: The condition, characterised by thigh pain during walking and a radiograph showing narrowing of vessels indicating blockage, is diagnosed as aortofemoral block, with the best surgical management being Aortofemoral Bypass. It is preferred when the block extends to distal iliac arteries. Grafts: Knitted/woven Dacron (needs preclotting) Collagen-impregnated Dacron/PTFE (does not require preclotting). PTA with stenting (Option A) , or percutaneous transluminal angioplasty with stenting, is a minimally invasive procedure used to treat narrowed or blocked blood vessels, particularly in the arteries. It is commonly performed to restore blood flow in peripheral arteries affected by atherosclerosis or other conditions. Femoroiliac bypass (Option B) , also known as femoral-to-iliac bypass or femoral bypass, is a surgical procedure used to treat peripheral artery disease (PAD) in the lower extremities. It involves creating a bypass graft to reroute blood flow around a narrowed or blocked femoral or iliac artery segment. Aorto-iliac bypass (Option D) , also

questions.question: According to the CEAP classification, What will be the stage in this patient as the patient presents with the same problem again and again?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) C2 Explanation: According to the CEAP (Clinical- Etiology- Anatomy- Pathology) , the stage in this case is C2, as the patient is experiencing recurrent symptoms, indicating that varicose veins are likely the underlying cause, which corresponds to stage C2. Feature Classification For clinical classification: No signs of venous disease Telangiectasia (<1 mm) or reticular veins ( 1-3 mm dilated veins) Varicose veins (>3 mm ) Edema Pigmentation or eczema LDS or atrophic blanche Corona phlebectatica Healed venous ulcer Active venous ulcer Clinical class can be further characterised as symptomatic (s), asymptomatic (a) or recurrent following previous successful treatment or healing (r), e.g. C2a, C2s, C6r. C0 C1 (Option B ruled out) C2 (Option A) C3 C4a (Option C ruled out) C4b C4c C5 (Option D ruled out) C6 For etiological classification: Congenital Primary Secondary (post-thrombotic) No venous cause identified Ec Ep Es En For anatomical classification: Superficial veins Perforator veins Deep veins No venous location identified As Ap Ad An For

questions.question: What is the appropriate course of action for managing a 25-year-old male patient who was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident? The patient has a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute and a blood pressure of 80/45 mmHg. During examination, hyper-resonance is detected on the right side of the chest. Please refer to the provided chest X-ray for further evaluation.

options.A: Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)
options.B: Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS

questions.explanation: 5th ICS Correct Answer: B) Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS Explanation : The patient presents with a traumatic injury after a road traffic accident . His clinical findings, along with the given chest X-ray, are suggestive of tension pneumothorax. A wide bore needle is inserted into the 5th intercostal space at the mid-axillary line to decompress the pleural space and allow the trapped air to escape, which is the first emergency intervention in suspected tension pneumothorax . After the initial needle decompression, the next step is to insert a chest tube (intercostal drain) in the same location to allow for continuous drainage of air or fluid from the pleural space. (Options A & D ruled out) This will help the lung re-expand and prevent the pneumothorax from recurring. Aspiration of the pleural fluid (Option C) is done for pleural effusion , where fluid accumulates in the pleural space. In this case, the clinical findings suggest pneumothorax , where air is trapped, not fluid. Therefore, aspiration is not the correct approach here. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 374

questions.question: A bus conductor was diagnosed with varicose veins. On examination, skin eczema and lipodermatosclerosis were noted. According to the CEAP classification system, he would be classified as:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) C4 Explanation : In this case, the bus conductor has skin eczema and lipodermatosclerosis , which are indicative of chronic venous insufficiency , hence classified as C4 . The CEAP (Clinical, Etiological, Anatomical, and Pathophysiological) classification system is used to classify chronic venous disorders CEAP (Clinical, Etiological, Anatomical, and Pathophysiological) classification Clinical classification: C0 No signs of venous disease C1 Telangiectasia (<1 mm) or reticular veins ( 1-3 mm dilated veins) C2 Varicose veins (>3 mm ) C3 Edema C4 C4a - Pigmentation or eczema C4b - LDS or atrophic blanche C4c - Corona phlebectatica C5 Healed venous ulcer C6 Active venous ulcer Clinical class can be further characterised as symptomatic (s), asymptomatic (a) or recurrent following previous successful treatment or healing (r), e.g. C2a, C2s, C6r. Etiological classification: Ec Congenital Ep Primary Es Secondary (post-thrombotic) En No venous cause identified Anatomical classification: As Superficial veins Ap Perforator veins Ad Deep veins An No venous location identified Pathophysiological classification: Pr Reflux Po Obstruction Pr,o Reflux and obstruction Pn No venous pathophysiology identified Pigmentation/Eczema: LDS: Atrophic blanche:

questions.question: In a 35-year-old individual with a history of chronic smoking who is experiencing bluish discoloration of the toes and intermittent claudication, what would be the most suitable investigation to conduct next?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Duplex scan Explanation : The most appropriate investigation to confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of the arterial occlusion in the lower limbs is a Duplex scan. The given case with chronic smoking, bluish toes, and intermittent claudication is suggestive of peripheral arterial disease (PAD), commonly linked to atherosclerosis in smokers. Duplex Doppler ultrasound (DUS) combines B-mode ultrasound for imaging vessels and Doppler ultrasound to assess blood flow, providing an accurate, cost-effective, and non-invasive alternative to angiography for detecting vascular issues. It is useful for initial evaluation but may have limitations in visualising deeper arteries. CT Angiography (Option A) is considered more specific and detailed imaging, and it’s not the first-line investigation for peripheral arterial disease (PAD). It is usually considered when other non-invasive tests (like duplex scans) are inconclusive or when a more detailed assessment is required. MR Angiography (Option B) is similar to CT angiography, which provides detailed vascular imaging but is not the initial choice. It's generally used when other methods are not feasible or are contraindicated. Digital subtraction angiography (Option C) is an invasive procedure that involves the injection of contrast dye into the blood vessels followed by X-ray imaging. It is generally reserved for cases where other imaging modalities have not provided sufficient information or when endovascular intervention (such as angioplasty) is planned. Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page 974. BMJ Link .

questions.question: Following a fight between 2 groups, a boy was brought with severe pain in the chest, distended neck veins, dyspnea, and a BP of 80/50 mmHg. X-ray shows the following findings: What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: distended neck veins (JVD), and hypotension (80/50 mmHg) suggest a life-threatening tension pneumothorax . Trauma history (fight) further supports the diagnosis. Increased Intrathoracic Pressure → Impaired Venous Return → Distended Neck Veins (JVD) As intrathoracic pressure rises, it compresses the superior vena cava (SVC) and right atrium , obstructing venous return to the heart. This results in jugular venous distension (JVD) due to backed-up blood in the venous system . Decreased Preload & Cardiac Output → Hypotension (Low BP) The compression of the right atrium and ventricle reduces blood filling (preload), decreasing stroke volume and cardiac output . This leads to severe hypotension and, if untreated, cardiac arrest due to obstructive shock. X-ray Findings: Hyperlucency (increased radiolucency) on the right side due to air accumulation. Mediastinal shift to the left due

questions.question: Which of the following adverse effects is not observed following a massive blood transfusion?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Hypercalcemia Explanation : Hypercalcemia is not commonly seen in massive blood transfusions. In fact, the risk is usually the opposite (hypocalcemia) due to citrate-binding calcium. Massive blood transfusion refers to the transfusion of a large volume of blood products over a relatively short period. While blood transfusions can be life-saving, they can also be associated with certain adverse effects. Complications of massive blood transfusion Complication Cause Effect Hypothermia Transfusion of cold blood (stored at 4°C). Body temperature drops, leading to impaired clotting mechanisms (coagulopathy) and worsening bleeding. Coagulopathy Dilution of clotting factors and platelets due to transfusion; consumption of clotting factors by ongoing haemorrhage. Impaired blood clotting, prolonged bleeding time, increased risk of continued bleeding. Citrate Toxicity Large volumes of transfused blood contain citrate, which binds to calcium. Hypocalcemia leads to muscle cramps, seizures, and cardiac arrhythmias. Hypocalcemia (Option A ruled out) Packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and other blood products are preserved with citrate , an anticoagulant. Citrate binds to ionised calcium (Ca² I ) in the recipient's blood, reducing the free calcium level - hypocalcemia Presents as muscle spasms, cardiac arrhythmias, and decreased myocardial contractility Hyperkalemia (Option D ruled out) Potassium leaks from stored red blood cells into plasma during storage. Elevated potassium levels (hyperkalemia) can cause cardiac arrhythmias, potentially leading to cardiac arrest. Hypokalemia (Option C ruled out) Potassium may shift intracellularly once transfused red blood cells are metabolically revived. Hypokalemia, causing muscle weakness, paralysis, and cardiac arrhythmias. Metabolic Alkalosis Rapid metabolism of citrate into bicarbonate. Increased pH (alkalosis) can lead to muscle twitching, irritability, and impaired oxygen release from haemoglobin. Metabolic Acidosis Inadequate tissue perfusion leads to lactic acid accumulation. Lowered blood pH (acidosis) leads to confusion, fatigue, rapid breathing, and worsened cardiovascular function. Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI) Antibodies in transfused blood activate the recipient's immune response, causing inflammation and fluid buildup in the lungs. Non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema, presenting as acute respiratory distress with hypoxia within 6 hours of transfusion. Transfusion Associated Circulatory Overload (TACO) Volume of transfused blood exceeds the patient’s capacity to manage, leading to fluid overload. Pulmonary edema, shortness of breath, hypertension, and signs of heart failure. Iron Overload Repeated transfusions lead to excessive accumulation of iron. Iron deposits in organs (e.g., liver, heart, pancreas), lead to organ damage and failure over time. Hemolytic Reactions ABO or Rh incompatibility. Rapid destruction of red blood cells (hemolysis), causing fever, chills, hemoglobinuria, and potentially acute renal failure or shock. Allergic Reactions Reaction to proteins in transfused blood products. Symptoms range from mild itching, rash, or hives to severe anaphylaxis (airway constriction, low blood pressure, shock). Bacterial Contamination Blood products are contaminated during collection or storage. Sepsis is characterized by fever, chills, low blood pressure, and possibly septic shock.

questions.question: A 55-year-old man with IHD presents with sudden, severe, generalised abdominal pain and multiple episodes of vomiting. On examination, the pulse rate is 118 bpm, rhythm is irregularly irregular, and BP is 90/60 mmHg. The abdomen appears soft and non-distended, and bowel sounds are absent. Which of the following could be a likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Acute mesenteric ischemia Explanation: Acute mesenteric ischemia is the most likely diagnosis due to the patient's risk factors (IHD), sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, vomiting, hypotension, and absent bowel sounds. This condition is caused by a reduction or cessation of blood flow to the intestines, leading to tissue ischemia. Acute mesenteric ischemia Aspects Description Definition Sudden reduction in blood supply to the intestines, leading to ischemia and potential necrosis. Commonly involves the Superior mesenteric artery (SMA). Clinical Features Pain: Severe, sudden-onset abdominal pain disproportionate to physical findings. Others: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, bloody stools, shock. Risk Factors Cardiovascular: Atrial fibrillation, recent MI, heart failure. Vascular: Atherosclerosis, vasculitis. Others: Hypercoagulable states. Radiological Features CT Angiography: Preferred diagnostic tool; reveals SMA occlusion, String of sausage sign , bowel wall thickening, pneumatosis intestinalis, portal venous gas. Management Initial: IV fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, pain control. Definitive: Anticoagulation (e.g., IV heparin), surgical embolectomy, bowel resection. Vasodilators (e.g., papaverine) can be used intra-arterially to relieve vasospasm. Acute severe pancreatitis (Option A) presents with severe epigastric pain that can radiate to the back, but not generalised abdominal pain. The patient also often has elevated pancreatic enzymes (amylase/lipase), and abdominal tenderness would usually be present. The absence of bowel sounds and the patient's cardiac symptoms are suggestive of acute mesenteric ischemia. Ruptured aortic aneurysm (Option B) is a life-threatening condition that causes severe, tearing abdominal pain and sudden, severe hypotension. This patient lacks key signs like a pulsatile mass, significant tenderness, or acute collapse, making it less likely. Peptic ulcer perforation (Option D) presents with acute abdominal pain, tachycardia, guarding and rigidity of the anterior abdominal wall, it can lead to peritonitis and sepsis. The soft, non-distended abdomen in this case and the absence of these physical findings suggest this is less likely.

questions.question: What is the management approach for a 50-year-old male patient who has a 40 mm abdominal aortic aneurysm detected during his routine annual checkup?

options.B: Surgery is indicated if the aneurysmal diameter is > 55mm
options.C: Urgently wheel the patient to OT for surgery
options.D: Surgery is indicated only if the aneurysm is > 77mm

questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Surgery is indicated if the aneurysmal diameter is > 55mm: According to guidelines, surgery is generally recommended for abdominal aortic aneurysms greater than 5.5 cm (55 mm) in diameter. Management of abdominal aortic aneurysm depends on the aneurysm size, symptoms, and patient’s condition. A 40 mm abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is considered smaller than the threshold for surgical intervention. (Option A ruled out) . Management of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) Aspect Details Surveillance Small AAAs (3.0–3.9 cm): Monitor every 2–3 years using ultrasound. Medium AAAs (4.0–5.4 cm): Monitor every 6–12 months with ultrasound. Large AAAs ( ≥ 5.5 cm): Surgical intervention recommended; if not, frequent imaging and clinical review. Medical Management Risk Factor Modification : Smoking Cessation Blood Pressure Control Cholesterol Management: Statins recommended. Surgical Intervention (Option C & D ruled out) I ndications for Surgery: Aneurysm Diameter ≥ 55 mm (High risk of rupture) Rapid Growth: > 5 mm increase in six months. Symptomatic AAAs : Consider surgery. Surgical Options : Open Surgical Repair: Using a Dacron graft, which is durable and has higher morbidity. Endovascular Aneurysm Repair (EVAR): Less invasive, requires long-term surveillance for complications. Reference: Sabiston, Text Book of Surgery, 21st Edition, Pages 1747 - 1751

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding intermittent claudication is accurate?

options.B: Most commonly felt in the calf muscles
options.D: Relieved after getting out of bed

questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Most commonly felt in the calf muscles: Intermittent claudication is a condition caused by peripheral arterial disease (PAD) , which leads to insufficient blood flow to the muscles, particularly during exercise or physical exertion. The pain is typically muscle pain , cramping , or aching , and it most commonly affects the calf muscles because of their large muscle mass and high demand for oxygen during activity. The pain occurs with activity and is relieved by rest . (Options A & D ruled out) Boyd's classification of intermittent claudication : Grade Description Grade 0: Asymptomatic No symptoms of claudication, even with exercise Grade I: Mild claudication Able to walk more than 200 meters (about 650 feet) before onset of symptoms Grade II: Moderate claudication Able to walk between 50 and 200 meters (about 160 to 650 feet) before onset of symptoms Grade III: Severe claudication Able to walk less than 50 meters (about 160 feet) before onset of symptoms Grade IV: Ischemic rest pain Pain occurs at rest or with minimal exertion Day-to-day distance is variable (Option C) and is incorrect because the distance a person can walk before pain sets in is usually fairly consistent over time in intermittent claudication. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 998, 999, NIH Link

questions.question: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 41-year-old female patient who presented with a twisted swelling on the scalp and face, accompanied by a pulsating sensation and a bruit heard during auscultation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Cirsoid Aneurysm: In this case, the most likely diagnosis is a cirsoid aneurysm , given the pulsatile swelling, the bruit heard on auscultation, and the location of the lesion (scalp/face). It is a vascular malformation characterised by abnormal communication between arteries and veins, leading to variceal dilatation of the draining veins . This results in a pulsatile swelling, often associated with a palpable thrill and an audible bruit, which are hallmark signs of this condition. The mass in a cirsoid aneurysm can cause cosmetic concerns and may also lead to local pain , headache , tinnitus , and hemorrhage . Treatment for cirsoid aneurysm typically involves surgical fistula repair through simple ligation or endovascular embolisation techniques (using coils or cyanoacrylate ). In some cases, gross total resection by a plastic surgery team is also done. Neurofibromatosis (Option A) is benign nerve sheath tumours (neurofibromas) that may present as skin nodules or masses. These tumours would not produce the characteristic pulsatile swelling or bruit associated with a cirsoid

questions.question: According to the TNM staging, a patient with lung cancer of size 2.5 cm is staged as:
