questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - T1c: Given that the tumour size is 2.5 cm , it falls under T1c (as it is > 2 cm but ≤ 3 cm). AJCC 8TH Edition of TNM Staging of Lung Carcinoma Primary Tumor (T) T1 T1a(mi) Minimally invasive carcinoma T1a ≤ 1 cm (Option D ruled out) T1b 1 - 2 cm (Option A ruled out) T1c 2 - 3 cm T2 Involvement of the main bronchus with the involvement of carina Involvement of visceral pleura Association with atelectasis or obstructive pneumonitis T2a 3 - ≤ 4 cm (Option C ruled out) T2b 4 - ≤ 5 cm T3 > 5 - ≤ 7 cm OR Direct invasion of the Chest wall, Phrenic nerve, Pericardium, (Or) Satellite nodules in the same lobe T4 > 7 cm in greatest dimension (Or) Any tumour with invasion of the mediastinum, diaphragm, heart, great vessels, recurrent laryngeal nerve, carina, trachea, oesophagus, spine (Or) Separate tumours in different lobes of the ipsilateral lung. Lymph Node (N) N1 Ipsilateral peribronchial and/or hilar nodes and intrapulmonary nodes N2 Ipsilateral mediastinal and/or subcarinal nodes N3 Contralateral mediastinal or hilar; ipsilateral/contralateral scalene/supraclavicular Distant Metastasis (M) M1 Distant metastasis M1a Tumor in contralateral lung or pleural/pericardial nodule/malignant effusion M1b Single extrathoracic metastasis, including single non-regional lymph node M1c Multiple extrathoracic metastases in one or more organs Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st Edition, Page 601

questions.question: Which of the following is not a component of Thoracoscore?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Complication of surgery The Thoracoscore is a risk assessment tool used to evaluate the operative risk in patients undergoing thoracic surgery , but complications of surgery are not a component of it. The components of thoracoscore are: Age: <55 years, 55-65 years, >65 years Sex ASA Classification: ≤ 2, ≥ 3 (Option C ruled out) Performance status (Zubrod scale): ≤ 2, ≥ 3 (Option A ruled out) Severity of dyspnea (Medical Research Council Scale): ≤ 2, ≥ 3 Surgery Priority: Elective, Urgent/Emergency (Option D ruled out) Extent of resection: Pneumonectomy, Other Diagnosis: Malignant, Benign Comorbidity score Reference: NIH Link

questions.question: What is the probable diagnosis for a 50-year-old male who is a long-term smoker and experiences pain in both thighs and buttocks while walking approximately 500 meters?

options.A: Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery
options.D: Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement Explanation: Given the bilateral claudication affecting the thighs and buttocks, along with the patient’s smoking history, the most probable diagnosis is arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement. The muscle group affected in claudication is one anatomical level below the level of arterial disease. Aortoiliac disease typically presents with bilateral symptoms such as pain in the buttocks , thighs , and sometimes the calves , which worsens with exertion. The pain is due to claudication caused by reduced blood flow to the lower extremities due to atherosclerosis or stenosis, commonly associated with chronic smoking. Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery (Option A) generally causes pain in the calf , not the thighs or buttocks , and it usually affects one leg, not both. Therefore, the bilateral nature of the pain makes this diagnosis less likely. Femoral venous insufficiency (Option C) presents with swelling & varicose veins rather than claudication pain. The pain described here is intermittent and related to exertion, which is more typical of arterial disease, not venous insufficiency. Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery (Option D) would lead to pain in the thigh (and possibly one leg), not typically in both the thigh and buttock . Also, the pattern of bilateral pain favours the involvement of aortoiliac vessels . Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1024

questions.question: What would be the appropriate course of action for managing a 25-year-old male patient who was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident (RTA)? The patient has a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute and a blood pressure of 80/45 mmHg. During examination, hyper-resonance is detected over the left side of the chest. The provided chest x-ray is shown below.

options.A: Wide bore needle insertion in the right 5th ICS
options.B: Wide bore needle insertion in the left 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Wide bore needle insertion in the left 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain with the given chest X-ray suggest tension pneumothorax. A wide bore needle is inserted into the 5th intercostal space at the mid-axillary line to decompress the pleural space and allow the trapped air to escape, which is the first emergency intervention in suspected tension pneumothorax . After the initial needle decompression, the next step is to insert a chest tube (intercostal drain) in the same location to allow for continuous drainage of air or fluid from the pleural space. (Options A & D ruled out) This will help the lung re-expand and prevent the pneumothorax from recurring. Aspiration of the pleural fluid (Option C) is done for pleural effusion , where fluid accumulates in the pleural space. In this case, the clinical findings suggest pneumothorax , where air is trapped, not fluid. Therefore, aspiration is not the correct approach here. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 374

questions.question: After a road traffic accident, a patient was brought to the emergency department with chest injuries. The patient's respiratory rate is elevated at 44 breaths per minute, and their blood pressure is 90/40 mm/Hg. Although conscious, the patient can only speak single words. On examination, hyper-resonance is noted on the affected side of the chest. What would be your next immediate course of action?

options.B: Insert needle in appropriate intercostal space

questions.explanation: aspiration. A healthcare professional inserts a needle or catheter into the chest to remove the trapped air and allow the lung to re-expand. This procedure may be performed at the bedside or in a medical facility, and it is typically guided by imaging, such as ultrasound or chest X-ray. Put a large bore needle into the 2ndI/C space in the Midclavicular line Definitive Rx/ TOC- ICD insertion in Triangle of safety (5th I/C space in Anterior-axillary line) Incorrect Options: Option A, intubation, may be necessary if the patient's respiratory status deteriorates further, but it is not the immediate step to take. Option C , starting intravenous fluids urgently, is important for stabilizing the patient's blood pressure, but it may not address the underlying issue of tension pneumothorax causing hyper-resonance and respiratory distress. Option D , taking a chest X-ray, can help confirm the diagnosis and guide further management, but in a critically unstable patient with signs of tension pneumothorax, immediate intervention is required before obtaining diagnostic imaging. Therefore, the most appropriate immediate step to relieve the tension pneumothorax and improve the patient's respiratory status would be to insert a needle in the appropriate intercostal space, allowing air to escape and reducing the pressure in the pleural cavity.

questions.question: What is the likely diagnosis for a 40-year-old woman who comes to the emergency room after a road traffic accident? She has a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 15/15, a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg, and an elevated jugular venous pressure. Percussion reveals hyper-resonance and decreased breath sounds in the right chest, while the left chest appears normal. However, the patient is experiencing difficulty breathing and there is bruising on the chest wall. The abdomen feels soft.
questions.explanation: pneumothorax is a medical emergency characterized by the accumulation of air in the pleural space, leading to increased pressure and compression of the lung. It typically occurs as a result of trauma or injury to the chest, such as a rib fracture or lung laceration. In this scenario, the patient's history (RTA) suggests the possibility of chest trauma. The findings on examination provide clues to the diagnosis: Hyperresonant percussion and decreased breath sounds on the right side: This indicates the presence of air in the pleural space, resulting in a collapsed lung. Dyspnea: The patient's difficulty in breathing is likely due to the collapsed lung and impaired gas exchange. Elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP): The increased JVP may be observed in tension pneumothorax due to impaired venous return to the heart as a result of increased intrathoracic pressure. Ecchymosis over the chest wall: This bruising may suggest underlying trauma or injury to the chest. Incorrect Options: The other options can be ruled out based on the clinical presentation: Option A . Cardiac tamponade typically presents with signs of hemodynamic compromises, such as low blood pressure, narrowed pulse pressure, and distant heart sounds. The absence of these findings makes it less likely. Option C . Pericardial effusion may cause symptoms related to cardiac compressions, such as muffled heart sounds, jugular venous distention, and signs of heart failure. These findings are not present in this case. Option D . Massive hemothorax involves the accumulation of blood in the pleural space, leading to similar symptoms as tension pneumothorax. However, in this scenario, the hyper resonant percussion and decreased breath sounds suggest the presence of air rather than blood. Prompt recognition and management of tension pneumothorax are essential. Immediate intervention, such as needle decompression or chest tube insertion, is necessary to relieve the pressure, re-expand the lung, and restore normal breathing.

questions.question: A 50-year-old diabetic man presents with a progressive increase in pain in his calf. He now prefers to sleep in a seated position by hanging his leg to alleviate pain.Pain is more in the distal part like toes and feet. It gets aggravated with movements and pressure. The pain is increased in lying down and elevation of foot; it may be reduced on hanging the foot down. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation: information, is rest pain. Rest pain It is continuous aching in calf or feet and toes or in the region even at rest depending on site of obstruction. It is a ‘ cry of dying nerves’ due to ischemia of the somatic nerves. It signifies severe decompensated ischemia. Pain gets aggravated by elevation and is relieved in dependent position of the limb Pain is more in the distal part like toes and feet. It gets aggravated with movements and pressure. Rest pain is increased in lying down and elevation of foot; it may be reduced on hanging the foot down. Incorrect Choices: Option b: Sciatica is a condition that causes pain, numbness, or weakness in the lower back, buttocks, and legs due to compression or irritation of the sciatic nerve. However, the patient's symptoms of worsening pain with walking and relief by hanging the leg are inconsistent with sciatica. Option c: Neurogenic claudication is another possible cause of the patient's symptoms, which occurs due to spinal stenosis or nerve root compression, causing pain, numbness, and weakness in the lower back, buttocks, and legs. However, the patient's symptoms of worsening pain with walking and relief by hanging the leg are not typical of neurogenic claudication. Option d: Venous claudication is caused by chronic venous insufficiency, leading to decreased blood flow and oxygen supply to the affected tissues. However, the patient's symptoms of worsening pain with walking and relief by hanging the leg are not typical of venous claudication. Reference: .

questions.question: A 62-year-old male presents with left leg swelling and pain for 5 days and has a positive D-dimer test. Duplex ultrasonography confirms an extensive DVT involving the left popliteal and femoral veins. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management strategy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) LMWH followed by oral anticoagulant Explanation: Treatment of DVT: Anticoagulation: For initial management of acute DVT without contraindications to anticoagulation, the current recommended approach is to start with LMWH and transition to an oral anticoagulant. This approach has several advantages: LMWH provides rapid anticoagulation without the need for monitoring. Oral anticoagulants have shown non-inferiority or superiority to warfarin in large clinical trials. They have a better safety profile and do not require regular INR monitoring. This regimen allows for outpatient management in many cases, reducing hospitalization rates. Investigation of DVT: Venous Doppler with Duplex scanning Non-invasive; detects thrombus by impaired blood flow and inability to compress veins. Presence of echogenic material completely filling the lumen of vein Absence of compressibility Absence of blood flow Venogram Accurate for detecting and locating thrombus and differentiating occlusive and non-occlusive thrombus but less commonly used due to invasiveness. Impedance Plethysmography Measures changes in venous volume and flow using a cuff. Less useful for calf DVT and previous thrombosis. Fibrin and Fibrinogen Assays Measures fibrin degradation products, including D-dimer. D-dimer has a high negative predictive value. Radioactive Fibrinogen Study Uses radiolabeled fibrinogen to detect thrombus. Less commonly used. Magnetic Resonance Venous Imaging (MRVI) Non-invasive; Useful for imaging iliac veins and IVC. Management of DVT : Initial Anticoagulation Subcutaneous LMWH: Rapidly anticoagulate confirmed DVT cases. Intravenous Unfractionated Heparin: For patients with significant renal impairment. Fondaparinux or Bivalirudin: Alternatives for those with heparin sensitivity or heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. Transition to Oral Anticoagulation Duration: At least 3 months or longer based on risk factors or recurrence. Novel anticoagulants (NOACs): Rivaroxaban, Apixaban (factor Xa inhibitors), Dabigatran (direct thrombin inhibitor). Vitamin K Antagonists: Warfarin (alternative to NOACs). Monitoring Anticoagulation Heparin: Activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT). Warfarin: INR maintained between 2.0 to 3.0. For Patients with contraindications to Anticoagulation Temporary IVC Filter: Consider if bleeding risk prevents anticoagulation or to prevent pulmonary embolism. It does not treat the existing thrombus and is associated with long-term complications. (Option D) Endovascular Surgery Thrombus removal, lysis, and stenting. Beneficial in selected patients, especially those with iliofemoral thrombosis, to reduce risk of chronic post-thrombotic syndrome. Unfractionated heparin followed by warfarin (Option A) was the traditional approach. But it has largely been superseded by LMWH and DOACs due to the need for hospitalization, frequent aPTT monitoring for unfractionated heparin, and long-term INR monitoring for warfarin. Catheter-directed thrombolysis (Option C) is generally reserved for massive iliofemoral DVT with severe symptoms or limb-threatening situations. It carries a higher risk of bleeding and is not first-line therapy for most DVT cases.

questions.question: A chronic smoker presents with leg pain after walking 100 meters. On examination, there is an absent pulse in the bilateral dorsalis pedis, anterior tibial, and posterior tibial arteries, but no gangrene is noted. Intermittent claudication is suspected. Which of the following statements about this condition is correct?

options.A: Pain is more at night and sleep
options.B: Pain aggravated by standing and relieved by bending forward
options.C: Development of pain on the 1st step of walking
options.D: Pain develops after walking some distance and is relieved by rest

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Pain develops after walking some distance and is relieved by rest Explanation: Pain develops after walking some distance and relieved by rest is the correct description of intermittent claudication . This is a classic symptom of peripheral artery disease (PAD) . The pain is typically muscle pain , cramping , or aching , and it most commonly affects the calf muscles because of their large muscle mass and high demand for oxygen during activity. Boyd's classification of intermittent claudication : Grade Description Grade 0: Asymptomatic No symptoms of claudication, even with exercise Grade I: Mild claudication Able to walk more than 200 meters (about 650 feet) before onset of symptoms Grade II: Moderate claudication Able to walk between 50 and 200 meters (about 160 to 650 feet) before onset of symptoms Grade III: Severe claudication Able to walk less than 50 meters (about 160 feet) before onset of symptoms Grade IV: Ischemic rest pain Pain occurs at rest or with minimal exertion Pain is more at night and sleep (Option A) : Night pain is more characteristic of rest pain in advanced PAD, not intermittent claudication. Pain aggravated by standing and relieved by bending forward (Option B) : This description is more consistent with neurogenic claudication and is typical of lumbar canal stenosis , where pain worsens with standing or walking and is relieved by bending forward or sitting. Development of pain on the 1st step of walking (Option C) is associated with osteoarthritis , whereas the pain in intermittent claudication develops after walking for a certain distance, not immediately when taking the first step. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 998, 999.

questions.question: Which type of ulcer is given below?
questions.explanation: around the ankles. They typically have irregular borders, are shallow, and may present with a moist base. They are associated with chronic venous insufficiency, where poor blood flow in the veins leads to high pressure and fluid leakage in the tissues. The skin around the ulcer may be discolored or have signs of eczema. Incorrect Options: Option B - Arterial ulcer: These ulcers are generally found on the feet or toes and are characterized by well-defined, punched-out edges. They are usually painful, and the skin around the ulcer is often pale or cool to the touch. Arterial ulcers result from poor blood flow due to arterial disease, such as peripheral artery disease (PAD), which impairs oxygen and nutrient delivery to tissues. Option C - Trophic ulcer: Trophic ulcers are less common and are associated with conditions that cause nerve damage, such as diabetes or leprosy. These ulcers are typically painless and occur on areas prone to trauma or pressure. The affected skin may be dry and necrotic, and the ulcers are usually located on areas with poor sensation. Option D - Diabetic foot: Diabetic foot ulcers can occur anywhere on the foot and are often associated with diabetes-related neuropathy and peripheral vascular disease. They are typically found on pressure points and can have a deep, necrotic base. The ulcers may be surrounded by calloused skin and are often complicated by infection.

questions.question: What is the appropriate management for a patient presenting with constant chest pain and radiological findings of stanford type A aortic dissection?
questions.explanation: dissection, especially if the dissection involves the ascending aorta or if there are signs of compromise to vital organs. Surgery is typically required for Type A aortic dissections (involving the ascending aorta) due to the high risk of life-threatening complications. Immediate surgical repair aims to stabilize the aorta, prevent further dissection, and manage complications. Incorrect Options: Option B - Vasodilator: Vasodilators alone are not typically the first-line treatment for aortic dissection. While they can help manage hypertension, they do not address the critical need to control the force of blood flow through the aorta, which is crucial in the acute management of dissection. Option C - Beta Blocker: Beta blockers are a cornerstone in the medical management of aortic dissection. They reduce heart rate and blood pressure, thereby decreasing the shear stress on the aortic wall and preventing further dissection. Beta blockers are particularly important in Type B dissections (involving only the descending aorta) where surgery may not be immediately necessary. Option D - Beta Blocker plus Vasodilator: In some cases, a combination of beta blockers and vasodilators may be used to manage blood pressure and reduce heart rate. However, for aortic dissection, the immediate priority is to control blood pressure and heart rate, with beta blockers being the primary treatment. Vasodilators can be used in conjunction if needed to further control blood pressure, but they are not a replacement for beta blockers.

questions.question: A patient presented to the outpatient department with a dilated, tortuous vein in the leg. The patient reported a history of trauma to the same area 10 years prior. Upon examination, a pulsatile vein was also noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) A-V Fistula Explanation: The pulsatile nature of the vein in this case suggests an A-V fistula , as it indicates direct arterial blood flow into the venous system. The patient's history of trauma further supports this diagnosis, since A-V fistulas can result from penetrating injuries or iatrogenic causes. Arteriovenous Fistula (AVF) AVF is a communication between an artery and a vein that may be either congenital or acquired (trauma or surgical) . Structurally, they are arterialised (become dilated, tortuous and thick-walled). Physiologically, there is an increase in venous return (as blood starts flowing from arteries to veins, which causes an increase in cardiac output, which in turn results in an increase in systolic BP, leading to cardiac failure. On examination, there is a presence of pulsatile swelling, a thrill and auscultation reveals machinery murmur (buzzing continuous murmur) Nicoladoni’s / Branham’s sign is observed in AVF: On pressing the artery proximal to the fistula, there is a decrease in the size of the pulsatile mass, disappearance of palpable thrill and decrease in heart rate. Surgically created Arterio-Venous fistula: It is commonly used for patients with end-stage renal disease who require hemodialysis. Aspect Details Purpose Used for hemodialysis Provides high blood flow for effective dialysis Site Selection Prefer distal placement Non-dominant arm is typically used Arterial Quality Requires a strong arterial pulse for success Vein Preservation Avoid placing venous lines in the arm intended for fistula Examples of Surgically created fistulas are: Brescia-Cimino fistula: It is created between the Radial artery and the Cephalic vein. Snuff Box fistula: It is created between the Posterior branch of the radial artery and Cephalic vein Feinberg fistula: It is created between the Radial artery and the Basilic vein. Incorrect Options: Varicose veins (Option A) are dilated, tortuous veins, but they are not pulsatile and are typically not associated with trauma or arterial involvement. Angiofibromas (Option B) are benign tumors of blood vessels and fibrous tissue, but they would not typically present with a pulsatile vein or a history of trauma. Hemangiomas (Option C) are benign vascular tumors that usually appear as red or blue lesions and are not typically pulsatile. They are more common in infants and children.

questions.question: An elderly man with a chronic history of IV drug use presents with progressively increasing swelling in the groin on the right side. The swelling is non-fluctuant but pulsatile on examination. He has diminished pulses distal to the swelling on the same side. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) CT angiography followed by surgery Explanation: The pulsatile nature of the swelling, along with diminished distal pulses & history of chronic IV drug use , most likely suggests pseudoaneurysm. CT angiography is the gold standard for diagnosing pseudoaneurysms, as it provides detailed imaging of the blood vessels and helps in planning surgical or endovascular repair. Surgical treatment or endovascular embolisation may be required depending on the size and location of the pseudoaneurysm. Aspect True Aneurysm False (Pseudoaneurysm) Definition Involves all three layers of the arterial wall. Involves only a layer of fibrous tissue outside the vessel. Wall Structure Intima, media, and adventitia are involved. Only fibrous tissue surrounds the breach. Morphology Fusiform or saccular. Typically spherical or ovoid. Aetiology Atherosclerosis, genetic conditions. Trauma, surgery, or arterial puncture. Clinical Features May be asymptomatic until complications arise. Often presents with a pulsatile mass or pain. Common Locations Large arteries (e.g., aorta, iliac). Peripheral arteries (e.g., femoral, popliteal). Diagnosis Detected by ultrasound, CT, and MRI. Detected by ultrasound or angiography. Management Surgical repair or endovascular techniques. Repair or percutaneous methods (e.g., thrombin injection). Incorrect Options: Oral antibiotics and observation (Option B) would not be appropriate here because there is no indication of infection (e.g., no fluctuance or signs of abscess), and this is a likely vascular issue requiring surgical intervention. Compression stockings (Option C) are used to treat venous insufficiency or varicose veins. Incision and drainage (Option D) are typically used for abscesses or collections of pus, & should be avoided in this case.

questions.question: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department after sustaining a stab wound to the right side of his chest. He is in acute distress, with a heart rate of 120 beats per minute, blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute. On physical examination, there are decreased breath sounds on the left side. A chest X-ray is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: unstable. The X-ray shows haziness on the right side of the lung and collapse of the lung indicating hemothorax Clinical features of hemothorax Hypovolemic shock (due to loss of blood) Flat neck veins Dyspnea (because of collection of fluid in the pleural space) Unilateral absence of breath sounds (on auscultation) Dullness on percussion Incorrect Options: Option A - Pneumothorax: Pneumothorax can be spontaneous or secondary which usually presents with shortness of breath and underlying lung disease in secondary pneumothorax. Option C -

questions.question: A patient presents with calf pain while walking a certain distance. The pain is severe enough that he must stop and rest before continuing. According to Boyd's grading, which of the following grades best describes this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Grade 3 Explanation: Grade III is characterised by pain that persists during walking, and the patient has to stop and rest to relieve the pain. Boyd's classification of intermittent claudication : Grade Description Grade I Pain develops after walking a certain distance (claudication distance). The pain subsides due to increased blood flow and collateral circulation. Grade II Pain persists even while continuing to walk, but the patient can still walk with effort. Grade III Patient must stop and rest to relieve the pain; walking becomes significantly impaired. Grade IV Patient experiences rest pain, and the pain persists even at rest, indicating severe arterial disease. Reference: SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 162

questions.question: A man presented with a history of stab injury over the arm. On examination, there was the presence of hematoma, and radial and ulnar pulses were not felt. A 3.5 cm longitudinal tear is noted in the brachial artery. Which of the following is the best treatment option?

options.B: Repair with great saphenous vein graft

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Repair with great saphenous vein graft Explanation: In this patient with a longitudinal tear to the brachial artery due to a stab injury, the best treatment is to repair it with a great saphenous vein interposition graft harvested from an uninjured leg. Great saphenous vein is the ideal graft: Matches arterial pulsatile flow and size. ( Elastic property) Non-thrombogenic with superior long-term patency. Best for small vessels like popliteal and tibial arteries. Other grafts: Cephalic vein and lesser saphenous vein can be used, but the cephalic vein may be problematic in trauma cases. Timing of Definitive Repair: It is performed once: Hemorrhage is controlled. Coagulopathy and acidosis are corrected. Body temperature is normalised. End-to-end anastomosis (Option A) can only be done when the arterial ends can be easily approximated without tension. If there is a significant gap or tension, a graft is necessary to bridge the gap. Prosthetic grafts (Option C) , such as PTFE (polytetrafluoroethylene), are used in cases where there is trauma to the native saphenous vein or a size mismatch between the artery and the graft. Prosthetic grafts are often considered when vein grafts are not available or not suitable. PTFE is effective for proximal injuries (brachial, popliteal) but inferior for more distal extremity injuries. Saphenous vein patch (Option D) is primarily used to close arteriotomy sites in procedures like carotid endarterectomy , where a patch is used to widen the artery or close the site of an incision, rather than being used for a direct tear repair. Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 1800

questions.question: After undergoing surgery to correct a left-sided varicocele, a 30-year-old male patient inquires about the primary route through which venous drainage occurs following the surgery. How should the surgeon correctly respond to the patient's question?

options.C: Ectopic drainage in the iliac fossa

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Cremasteric veins Explanation: After surgery for a varicocele, which involves ligating the abnormal veins in the scrotum, venous drainage is redirected through the cremasteric veins . These veins are part of the venous system of the spermatic cord and are an important alternative route for venous drainage from the testicle once the abnormal venous flow is corrected. Varicocele: Pathophysiology: The pampiniform plexus drains the testis and epididymis. The testicular veins converge at the inguinal ring and ascend retroperitoneally. The left testicular vein drains into the left renal vein, and the right testicular vein drains into the inferior vena cava. Cremasteric veins provide an alternative venous return, draining into the inferior epigastric veins. Causes: Antireflux valve failure at the junction of the testicular vein and renal vein or inferior vena cava causes reflux. Nutcracker effect from compression of the left testicular vein between the superior mesenteric artery and aorta. Angulation at the junction of the left testicular vein and renal vein. Rare causes include renal tumours , deep vein thrombosis , and pampiniform plexus thrombosis . An isolated right-sided varicocele warrants imaging to rule out retroperitoneal masses. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1563

questions.question: A 39-year-old male who had a road traffic accident and suffered from chest trauma was admitted to the ER. About 1800 ml of blood loss from the chest tube in an hour. What is the next step in management for this condition?
questions.explanation: trauma with heavy bleeding in the lungs and significant blood loss (1800 ml) from the chest tube in an hour, an emergency thoracotomy is the appropriate next step. A thoracotomy involves making an incision into the chest wall to access the thoracic cavity. This procedure allows direct control of bleeding, repair of injuries, and potential life-saving measures. Given the severity of the situation and the rapid blood loss, immediate surgical intervention is necessary. Incorrect Options: Option B - Conservative for next 6 hours: Conservative management involves monitoring and treating the patient without immediate surgical intervention. However, in a case of heavy bleeding with ongoing blood loss, waiting for 6 hours is not appropriate. This delay could lead to further deterioration and worsening of the patient's condition. Option C - Continue resuscitation: While resuscitation is important, in a situation with significant and ongoing blood loss as described, simply continuing resuscitation without addressing the underlying cause (bleeding) may not be effective. Direct intervention to control the bleeding is crucial. Option D - Wait & watch: Waiting and watching the patient's condition without taking immediate action to control the bleeding could be dangerous in this scenario. The patient is actively bleeding with a large volume of blood loss, which requires prompt intervention to stabilize their condition. Reference: .

questions.question: In a patient with aortic dissection, injury to which of the following structure will cause hiccups?
questions.explanation: cause hiccups. Phrenic nerve receives contributions from the cervical nerve roots (C3-C5) and travels along the mediastinum and pericardium, running close to the thoracic aorta. An aortic dissection, particularly involving the ascending aorta or arch, can lead to irritation or compression of the phrenic nerve, causing it to become hyperactive. This hyperactivity can manifest as hiccups, which are involuntary contractions of the diaphragm. Incorrect options: Option B, C and D are incorrect.

questions.question: A 56-year-old patient presented with varicose veins. What is the investigation of choice for varicose veins?
questions.explanation: non-invasive imaging technique that combines conventional ultrasound with Doppler ultrasound. It allows visualization of blood flow in the veins and can identify abnormalities, such as reflux (backward flow of blood) in the veins, which is a common finding in varicose veins. It provides valuable information about the anatomy and function of the veins, helping to guide treatment decisions. Incorrect options: Option B - Plethysmography: Plethysmography is a technique used to measure changes in the volume of an organ or limb. While it can provide information about blood volume changes, it is not as specific or accurate in diagnosing the underlying causes of varicose veins as duplex ultrasound. Option C - MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): While MRI can provide detailed images of soft tissues, it is usually reserved for more complex cases or when other imaging methods are inconclusive. Duplex ultrasound is preferred due to its cost-effectiveness and accuracy in diagnosing varicose veins. Option D - CT (Computed Tomography): CT scans involve ionizing radiation and are generally used for specific indications. Duplex ultrasound is safer, non-invasive and more suitable for evaluating venous abnormalities like varicose veins.

questions.question: A patient presents with dull, aching pain and tortuous veins in both lower limbs. Which test would be appropriate for evaluating superficial femoral vein (SFJ) competence?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Brodie Trendelenburg test Explanation: The Brodie-Trendelenburg test/ Trendelenburg I test is done to determine the patency of the saphenofemoral junction. Procedure: The patient is asked to lie in the supine position. The leg is elevated, the vein is emptied by “milking,” and a tourniquet is tied just below the saphenofemoral junction. The patient is asked to stand up quickly. The tourniquet is released. Observation: When there is rapid filling of blood from above, this signifies saphenofemoral incompetence. Other tests for varicose veins: Modified Perthe’s test (Option C) : For DVT After elevating the limb and emptying the veins, a tourniquet is applied at the SFJ and the patient is asked to walk around for a few minutes. If the dilated veins become more prominent, it signifies deep venous obstruction. Three tourniquet test: for specific perforator Fegan’s test for perforator (Option A) : On standing, the line of varicosity is marked, and then the veins are emptied in the supine position. The examiner palpates along the marked line and notices any pits or gaps in the deep fascia that signify perforator incompetence at that site. Pratt’s test for perforator: Applying pressure to the calf muscle; if it feels tense and causes pain, it may indicate acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Morrisey’s cough impulse test for SFJ incompetence: The patient is asked to turn their face away from the examiner and cough while the examiner keeps a finger at the SFJ, and an expansile cough impulse is felt. Signifies SFJ incompetence. Ian-Aird test for SFJ incompetence. Homan’s test (Option B) is a test for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) rather than venous insufficiency. It involves dorsiflexing the foot and assessing for pain in the calf, which may suggest a clot.

questions.question: A 40-year-old smoker presents with sudden, severe, tearing chest pain radiating to his back, shortness of breath, and mild nausea. His BP is 190/110 mmHg, and heart rate is 105 bpm. What is the initial management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Control Blood pressure Explanation: The case scenario of a smoker presenting with severe, tearing chest pain radiating to his back, shortness of breath, and mild nausea, along with a BP of 190/110 mmHg and heart rate of 105 bpm, is likely experiencing Aortic Dissection , where the initial management focuses on BP control. It occurs when a defect or a flap occurs in the aorta, resulting in blood tracking into aortic tissues, splitting the medial layer, and creating a false lumen. Clinical features Sudden onset of severe, tearing chest, radiating to the interscapular region Renal pain and renal failure Paraplegia Syncope Weakness Hypotension or shock Investigations Stable Patient: CT angiography is the standard investigation of choice. Unstable Patients (SBP<100 mm of HG, HR>100 bpm) : TEE (TransEsophageal Echocardiography) (preferred investigation of choice) MRI can also be done if CT is unequivocal. Chest x-ray reveals widening of mediastinum along with left-sided pleural effusion TEE of an aortic dissection within the descending part Management Initial Management: Initial management of all types of aortic dissection includes: Blood pressure control (which is usually high at presentation) (Option A) Strict pain management, Prompt referral for specialist management Surgical Management Type A (or type I and II) dissections Type B (or type III) dissections Those involving the ascending aorta usually require surgical intervention. Synthetic graft if needed Anastomosis Endovascular stenting of type A dissections. Initial management: Antihypertensive drugs Monitoring on an acute care unit Complicated cases: If pain worsens, fails to resolve, or malperfusion signs appear (e.g., organ, limb, or neurological symptoms) Percutaneous endovascular stents Surgery (rarely used) Urgent surgery (Option B) : Although surgery is often required for aortic dissection, blood pressure control is the initial and most critical step before surgery. Stabilizing the patient with medications like labetalol helps reduce the force on the aorta, preventing further dissection or rupture. Surgery would follow once the patient is stabilized. Wait and watch (Option C) is not an option for aortic dissection. Aortic dissection is a medical emergency that requires immediate intervention. Delaying treatment with a "wait and watch" approach can lead to life-threatening complications, such as rupture or organ failure. Blood transfusion (Option D) may be necessary if there is significant blood loss, but it is not the first line of management for aortic dissection. The priority is stabilizing the patient with blood pressure control to minimize the risk of further dissection or rupture before considering other interventions like a transfusion.

questions.question: Which is the least commonly used graft for coronary artery bypass graft (CABG)?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Intercostal artery Explanation: The intercostal artery is the least commonly used graft in Coronary Artery Bypass Graft (CABG) due to its limited availability and potential complications, with the long saphenous vein, internal mammary artery, and radial artery being preferred options. It is a procedure done by using a vascular graft for bypassing the blocked site of arteries and allowing the flow of blood to the heart muscles. Indications: Triple vessel stenosis Left main stem stenosis Chronic stable angina Angina with persistent chest pain >70% blockage of coronary vessels Classification of Vascular grafts: Bioprosthetic grafts LIMA (Left Internal Mammary Artery) (Option B ruled out) Long saphenous vein: Most commonly used in infra-inguinal surgeries due to small and medium-sized vessels. (Option A ruled out) Synthetic grafts Dacron: Most commonly used synthetic graft in supra inguinal surgeries due to large vessels. Polyurethane ePTFE (expanded polytetrafluoroethylene) Most preferred graft for CABG is LIMA , but the Long saphenous vein is more commonly used due to its extra length and it is easy to handle. Radial artery (Option D) is a commonly used graft in CABG, offering comparable long-term patency to the internal mammary artery and is particularly useful for smaller coronary arteries. It’s a good alternative to vein grafts, but requires careful harvesting and postoperative monitoring for complications. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 946-953.

questions.question: All of the following are anterior mediastinal tumors except:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Lymphoma Explanation: Lymphoma is a tumor of the middle mediastinum, not the anterior mediastinum. Tumors of mediastinum Anterior mediastinum Middle mediastinum Posterior mediastinum Thymomas (Option D ruled out) Thymic carcinomas Thymic cyst Germ cell tumors (Option C ruled out) Lymphomas Parathyroid adenomas (Option A ruled out) Carcinoid tumour Fibroma Lymphomas (Option B) Tumors of the heart and great vessels Tumours of the trachea, mainstem bronchi, and oesophagus Aortic pathologies such as aortic aneurysm, abscess, or dissection. Pericardial cysts Bronchogenic cysts Neuroenteric cyst Mesothelial cyst Pheochromocytoma Neurilemomas (schwannomas) Neurofibromas Ganglioneuromas Ganglioneuroblastomas Neuroblastomas Pheochromocytomas Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 991-993. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 1587,1633. Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page 728. SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 1110.

questions.question: A 17-year-old woman with no comorbidities presents with numbness and paraesthesia of the fingers along with the characteristic finding as shown in the image below. She has no history of smoking or history of other illnesses. She mentions the episodes occur when she is under excess stress or during cold temperatures. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Raynaud’s phenomenon Explanation: The scenario of a young woman experiencing numbness, paresthesia, and bluish discoloration of the fingers during cold stress or excessive stress, with no comorbidities, smoking history, or other illnesses, is most likely diagnosed as Raynaud's Phenomenon . Category Description Definition It is characterized by episodic reduction in blood flow, typically in the fingers, triggered by cold exposure or stress. Clinical Features Pallor: Skin becomes pale or white due to reduced blood flow. Cyanosis: Skin turns blue or purple due to deoxygenation of blood. Rubor: Skin turns red as blood flow returns, often with swelling and tingling. Cold Sensitivity: Cold, numb fingers. Pain: Pain during the cyanotic phase. Swelling and Tingling: Occurs in the rubor phase. Types Primary Raynaud Phenomenon (Raynaud Disease): Occurs without underlying disease. More common and has a better prognosis. Secondary Raynaud

questions.question: A patient with varicose veins complains of eczema in the same region. According to the CEAP guidelines, what is the stage of the clinical classification?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) C4a Explanation: According to the CEAP (Clinical, Etiological, Anatomical, and Pathophysiological) classification system for chronic venous disease, C4a refers to skin changes such as eczema or pigmentation in the presence of varicose veins. The CEAP (Clinical- Etiology- Anatomy- Pathology) classification for chronic venous disorders: Clinical Classification (C): Class Description C0 No visible or palpable signs of venous disease C1 Telangiectasia or reticular veins (<1–3 mm) C2 Varicose veins (>3 mm) C3 Edema without skin changes C4a Pigmentation or eczema C4b Lipodermatosclerosis (LDS) or atrophie blanche C4c Corona phlebectatica C5 Healed venous ulcer C6 Active venous ulcer Each class can be followed by a modifier : a = Asymptomatic s = Symptomatic r = Recurrent (after successful treatment/healing) Example : C2s, C6r Etiological Classification (E) Code Description Ec Congenital Ep Primary Es Secondary (e.g., post-thrombotic) En No venous etiology identified Anatomical Classification (A) Code Description As Superficial veins Ap Perforator veins Ad Deep veins An No venous location identified Pathophysiological Classification (P) Code Description Pr Reflux Po Obstruction Pr,o Reflux and obstruction Pn No identifiable pathology Pigmentation/Eczema LDS Atrophic blanche Corona phlebectatica

questions.question: Identify the given condition:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Trophic ulcer Explanation: Trophic ulcers, also called neuropathic ulcers, occur due to a loss of sensation and an impaired ability to protect the skin, often resulting from conditions like peripheral neuropathy or poor circulation. These ulcers usually have well-defined borders and a pale or pink wound bed, commonly located in weight-bearing areas where pressure or friction is frequent. Type of Ulcer: Type History Lesion Characteristics Pain Ischemic/Arterial Smoking, intermittent claudication Irregular edges, poor granulation tissue, dry necrotic base; round or punched-out with sharp demarcation Severe, particularly at night; relieved by dependency Venous Varicose veins, DVT, trauma, surgery, multiple pregnancies Shallow, irregular/shaggy shape, granulating base, fibrinous material with moderate to heavy exudate Mild; relieved by elevation Neurotrophic Numbness, paresthesias, burning, loss of sensation in the foot, DM Punched-out, deep sinus, variable depth, partial thickness to severe, involving the tendon, fascia, joint capsule, or bone None Malignant Ulcer History of skin cancer (e.g., basal or squamous cell carcinoma) Irregular, raised borders, ulcerating tumour with hard, indurated tissue Often painful, it can be associated with bleeding or foul odour

questions.question: A construction worker presents to the OPD with complaints of white fingers. He has been working in the cement and concrete industry and has spent 20 years using heavy machinery drills and polishing wood and furniture. What is the most likely etiology for this condition?

options.A: Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water
options.C: Continuous exposure to cement and concrete
options.D: Continuous exposure to drills and machines

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Continuous exposure to drills and machines Explanation: The patient's symptoms of white fingers are suggestive of the vibration-induced white finger (VWF) or hand-arm vibration syndrome (HAVS) , a secondary form of Raynaud syndrome, which is caused by prolonged exposure to vibrating tools and machinery. This condition leads to reduced blood flow and ischemia in the fingers, resulting in the characteristic whiteness of the fingers. Raynaud’s Syndrome: Raynaud’s syndrome is the peripheral arterial manifestation of a collagen vascular disease, such as systemic lupus erythematosus or rheumatoid arthritis. It shares clinical features with Raynaud’s disease but is often more severe. It can also occur due to vibrating tool use , a recognised industrial disease known as vibration white finger . Clinical features: The symptoms are similar to Raynaud’s disease but can be more aggressive. In secondary Raynaud’s syndrome (due to collagen diseases), there may be necrosis of digits and multiple amputations . Management: Primary treatment focuses on addressing the underlying condition . Conservative measures can be helpful, including: Nifedipine Steroids Vasospastic antagonists Sympathectomy generally provides poor outcomes and is not recommended . Prevention: Patients with a vibrated white finger should avoid vibrating tools to prevent further damage. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1024

questions.question: A patient presents with a sudden onset of chest pain shooting to the neck and interscapular region. X-ray shows a widened mediastinum. Blood pressure is 110/90 mmHg in the right upper limb and 160/100 mmHg in the left upper limb. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Acute aortic dissection Explanation: Acute aortic dissection often presents with sudden, severe chest pain radiating to the neck and interscapular region. A widened mediastinum on X-ray is a classic sign. The significant difference in blood pressure between the right and left upper limbs suggests aortic dissection, as it can cause unequal blood flow due to dissection of the aortic wall. Aortic Dissection: Occurs when a defect or a flap occurs in the aorta, resulting in blood tracking into aortic tissues, splitting the medial layer, and creating a false lumen. Clinical features: Sudden onset of severe, tearing chest, radiating to the interscapular region Renal pain and renal failure Paraplegia Syncope Weakness Hypotension or shock Investigations: If the patient is stable, CT angiography is the standard investigation of choice. In the case of unstable patients (SBP<100 mm of HG, HR>100 bpm), the preferred investigation of choice will be TEE (TransEsophageal Echocardiography)(Option C) MRI can also be done if CT is unequivocal. Chest x-ray reveals widening of mediastinum along with left-sided pleural effusion. TEE of an aortic dissection within the descending part DeBakey Classification (Based on the pattern of dissection) Type I Both ascending and descending aorta are involved Type II Only the ascending aorta is involved Type III Only the descending aorta is involved Stanford Classification (Based on whether the ascending aorta is involved in aortic dissection) Type A Only the ascending aorta or both ascending and descending aorta is involved. (It includes both Type I and Type II of DeBakey’s classification) Type B Only the descending aorta is involved. (It includes Type III of DeBakey’s classification) Acute coronary syndrome (Option A): This condition usually presents with central chest pain radiating to the left arm or jaw, often accompanied by sweating, nausea, and shortness of breath. The difference in blood pressure between the arms is not a characteristic feature of acute coronary syndrome. Acute pulmonary embolism (Option B) typically presents with sudden onset dyspnea, chest pain, and possibly hemoptysis. While an ECG might show signs of right heart strain or sinus tachycardia, it does not cause a discrepancy in blood pressure between the limbs. Esophageal rupture (Option D) often occurs after severe vomiting (e.g., Boerhaave's syndrome) and presents with severe chest pain. The X-ray would typically show mediastinal air rather than a widened mediastinum.

questions.question: A 62-year-old patient presents with pain in the calf muscles while walking. The pain subsides with rest. Which of the following is not typically seen in intermittent claudication?

options.A: Cramping in the muscles during exercise
options.B: Pain starting on taking the first step
options.C: The most common cause is atheroma
options.D: The level of occlusion cannot be decided based on symptoms

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Pain starting on taking the first step Explanation: Intermittent claudication typically involves cramping pain in the calf muscles during exercise (such as walking), which subsides with rest. The pain usually starts after walking for a certain distance and is relieved by rest, not immediately upon taking the first step. Boyd's classification of intermittent claudication : Grade Description Grade 0: Asymptomatic No symptoms of claudication, even with exercise Grade I: Mild claudication Able to walk more than 200 meters (about 650 feet) before onset of symptoms Grade II: Moderate claudication Able to walk between 50 and 200 meters (about 160 to 650 feet) before onset of symptoms Grade III: Severe claudication Able to walk less than 50 meters (about 160 feet) before onset of symptoms Grade IV: Ischemic rest pain Pain occurs at rest or with minimal exertion Incorrect Options: Cramping in the muscles during exercise (Option A) : Intermittent claudication is characterised by pain or cramping in the muscles during exercise, usually affecting the lower extremities. The most common cause is atheroma (Option C) : Atheroma, which is the accumulation of fatty plaques in the arteries, is the primary cause of intermittent claudication. The narrowing of the arteries due to atheroma restricts blood flow to the muscles during physical activity, resulting in pain. Level of occlusion cannot be decided based on symptoms (Option D) : The exact level of arterial occlusion cannot be determined by symptoms alone in intermittent claudication. Diagnostic tests, such as ankle-brachial index (ABI) or angiography, are needed to assess the location and extent of arterial blockage. ABI/ABPI: ABPI (Ankle brachial pressure index) is measured supine by checking the systolic blood pressure in both upper and lower limbs (brachial, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis arteries). The higher value from each limb is used to calculate the ABPI. This index is calculated as: ABI / ABPI = Systolic BP in the Ankle/ Systolic BP in the arm Interpretations are as follows: Value Interpretation 0.1 - 0.4 Critical limb ischemia 0.5 - 0.9 Intermittent claudication 1.0 - 1.2 Normal > 1.2 Calcified vessels (seen in patients with DM, End stage renal disease) Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 998,999 Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 1773

questions.question: What is the most preferred site for the insertion of the intercostal tube drain?
questions.explanation: because it helps to avoid injury to important structures like the neurovascular bundle that runs along the lower border of the rib. By inserting the needle just above the upper border of the lower rib, there's a decreased risk of damaging these structures. Incorrect options: Option B, C and D are not the preferred sites for the insertion of intercostal tube drain.

questions.question: What are the distinguishing features between cardiac tamponade and tension pneumothorax ?

options.D: Not improving after initial fluid resuscitation

questions.explanation: tamponade and tension pneumothorax. In cardiac tamponade, breath sounds are typically normal because the primary issue is compression of the heart. In tension pneumothorax, on the other hand, there may be absent or decreased breath sounds on the affected side due to lung collapse. Incorrect Options: Option A - Raised JVP (Jugular Venous Pressure): Both cardiac tamponade and tension pneumothorax can result in an elevated JVP. However, this is not a specific finding that can differentiate between the two conditions. Option C - Raised heart rate : Both cardiac tamponade and tension pneumothorax can lead to an increased heart rate. It is a non-specific finding and cannot be used to differentiate between the two conditions. Option D - Not improving after initial fluid resuscitation : This option is not specific to either cardiac tamponade or tension pneumothorax. It is more indicative of a lack of response to initial fluid resuscitation and can occur in various conditions. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: The given below device is :
questions.explanation: as intermittent pneumatic compression (IPC) devices or sequential compression devices (SCDs), are commonly used as a prophylactic measure to prevent deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in various clinical settings. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is the formation of a blood clot in the deep veins of the body, usually in the legs. It can be a serious condition that may lead to complications such as pulmonary embolism if the blood clot dislodges and travels to the lungs. Pneumatic compression stockings are designed to improve blood flow in the legs and reduce the risk of blood clot formation. These stockings are made of inflatable chambers or sleeves that are connected to a device that periodically inflates and deflates the chambers. When the pneumatic compression stockings are worn, the chambers sequentially inflate, applying gentle pressure to the legs in a specific pattern. This pressure helps to promote blood flow in the veins by compressing the superficial veins, thereby reducing venous stasis (slow blood flow) and enhancing venous return (blood flow back to the heart). The sequential inflation and deflation of the chambers create a pumping effect, mimicking the natural movement of the muscles during walking or exercising. This action helps prevent blood from pooling or stagnating in the veins, reducing the likelihood of blood clot formation. Pneumatic compression stockings are often used in situations where individuals are at an increased risk of developing DVT, such as during surgery, prolonged bed rest, or when mobility is limited. They are also utilized

questions.question: A 50-year-old male presents to the emergency with a BP of 160/100 mmHg and a heart rate of 120 . CECT done reveals a Stanford A aortic dissection. What is the initial management of this given condition?
questions.explanation: by a tear in the inner layer of the aorta, leading to the formation of a false lumen and separation of the arterial wall layers. Stanford A refers to a type of aortic dissection involving the ascending aorta. The initial management of Stanford A aortic dissection aims to reduce the shear forces acting on the aortic wall, lower blood pressure, and decrease the risk of propagation and rupture. Here's an explanation of the options: Incorrect Options: Option B - LMWH: LMWH (Low Molecular Weight Heparin) is not the initial management for Stanford A aortic dissection. Anticoagulation therapy is generally not recommended in the acute setting of aortic dissection due to the risk of increased bleeding complications. Option C - Beta blockers : This option is incorrect, used in type B aortic dissection Option D - Vitamin K inhibitors: Vitamin K inhibitors, such as warfarin, are not indicated in the initial management of Stanford A aortic dissection. They are commonly used for anticoagulation in conditions like atrial fibrillation or venous thromboembolism but are not the primary treatment for aortic dissection.

questions.question: An abdominal aortic aneurysm is operated when its size is greater than ____?
questions.explanation: of an AAA. Once an aneurysm reaches or exceeds this size, the risk of rupture significantly increases, and the potential benefits of surgical intervention to prevent rupture outweigh the risks associated with the procedure. Incorrect Options: Option A - 5 cm: This is below the generally accepted size threshold for surgical intervention. AAA measuring less than 5 cm in diameter are often monitored through regular imaging studies to detect any significant growth. Option B - 6 cm: While an AAA measuring 6 cm in diameter is larger and carries a higher risk of rupture, the threshold for elective repair is typically set at 5.5 cm. Option D - 6.5 cm: An AAA measuring 6.5 cm is considered a large aneurysm that poses a high risk of rupture. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: What is the most frequently encountered tumor in the mediastinum ?
questions.explanation: most common mediastinal mass are neurogenic tumors Incorrect Options: Option A - Thymoma: Thymoma is a tumor that originates from the thymus gland, which is located in the mediastinum. They are the most common anterior mediastinal mass Option C - Lymphoma: Lymphomas are cancers that originate from lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell. While lymphomas can involve the mediastinum, they are not as common as thymomas. Option D - Bronchial cyst: Bronchial cysts are abnormal fluid-filled sacs that develop within the bronchial walls. While they can occur in the mediastinum, they are not the most common mediastinal tumors. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Identify the lesion shown below?
questions.explanation: necrosis (death) that occurs in a moist or wet environment. It is usually caused by a severe bacterial infection and impaired blood supply to the affected area. The affected tissue appears swollen, discolored (often dark or black), and may have a foul odor. It is commonly seen in the extremities, such as the feet. In the given image, the appearance of the foot with discoloration, swelling, and signs of tissue decay suggests the presence of wet gangrene. The presence of a severe infection and impaired blood supply are consistent with this diagnosis. Incorrect Options: Option B - Dry gangrene: Dry gangrene is characterized by tissue death in a dry environment without the presence of infection. It usually occurs due to reduced blood supply to the affected area, leading to tissue necrosis. Dry gangrene often appears black, dry, and shriveled. Option C - Frostbite: Frostbite refers to tissue injury caused by extreme cold exposure. It occurs when prolonged exposure to freezing temperatures leads to damage to the skin and underlying tissues. Frostbite can cause discoloration, numbness, and blistering of the affected area. Option D - Ainhum: Ainhum is a rare condition characterized by the progressive constriction and autoamputation of the digits, usually the fifth toe. It typically affects individuals in certain geographical regions and is associated with the formation of a fibrous band around the affected digit. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: What is the most frequently observed complication in a 29-year-old man who visits the outpatient department due to pain, heaviness, and swelling in his right leg? The patient has been dealing with varicose veins since he was 12 years old. After undergoing below-knee stripping of the long saphenous vein, both the symptoms and visible varicose veins disappeared.
questions.explanation: burning pain along the course of a nerve. In the context of the patient's history of varicose veins and subsequent surgical intervention (below-knee stripping of the long saphenous vein), neuralgia can occur as a common complication. This can happen due to nerve damage during the surgical procedure or as a result of ongoing irritation or inflammation of the nerves in the affected area. Incorrect Options: Options A - Hemorrhage: Hemorrhage, or excessive bleeding, is a potential complication of any surgical procedure. However, in the given scenario, where the patient's symptoms resolved completely after the surgery, hemorrhage is less likely to be the most common complication. Options B - Thromboembolism: Thromboembolism refers to the formation of a blood clot (thrombus) that travels through the bloodstream and blocks a blood vessel. While varicose veins can increase the risk of blood clots, the patient's symptoms improved after the surgery, suggesting that thromboembolism is not the most common complication in this case. Options D - Infection: Infection is a possible complication of any surgical procedure. However, the patient's symptoms resolved after the surgery, making infection less likely to be the most common complication. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following are indications for surgical intervention in abdominal aortic aneurysms ?

options.A: Size more than 5.5 cm in males
options.B: Size more than 5 cm in females

questions.explanation: abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAAs). Option A - Size more than 5.5 cm in males: This criterion is based on the risk of rupture. An AAA larger than 5.5 cm in diameter has a higher risk of rupture, and surgical intervention is recommended to prevent rupture and its potentially life-threatening consequences. Option B - Size more than 5 cm in females: Although the threshold for surgical intervention is slightly lower in females compared to males, an AAA larger than 5 cm in diameter is still considered an indication for surgery in females. This is because females generally have a smaller aorta, and smaller aneurysms in women may carry a higher risk of rupture compared to men. Option C - Expansion of > 0.5 cm within 6 months: Rapid expansion of an AAA indicates an increased risk of rupture. If the aneurysm grows more than 0.5 cm within a 6-month period, surgical intervention is recommended to prevent rupture. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which complication is seen after the Varicose vein stripping procedure ?
questions.explanation: varicose veins, which are enlarged and twisted veins usually found in the legs. While varicose vein stripping is generally safe, complications can occur. One of the complications associated with this procedure is neuralgia, which refers to nerve pain or nerve damage. Neuralgia can manifest as persistent or intermittent pain along the distribution of the affected nerves. Incorrect Options: Options B - Deep vein thrombosis: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a condition characterized by the formation of blood clots in the deep veins, typically in the legs. While DVT is a possible complication of varicose veins themselves, it is not directly associated with the varicose vein stripping procedure. Options C - Acrocyanosis: Acrocyanosis is a condition characterized by persistent bluish discoloration of the hands and feet, usually due to reduced blood flow to the peripheral vessels. It is not a direct complication of varicose vein stripping. Options D - Telangiectasia: Telangiectasia refers to the dilation of small blood vessels near the surface of the skin, resulting in the appearance of fine red or purple lines. While telangiectasia may be associated with varicose veins, it is not a specific complication of the varicose vein stripping procedure. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which is the most common anterior mediastinal tumour?
questions.explanation: from the thymus gland and is typically slow-growing. Thymomas can be associated with autoimmune disorders and myasthenia gravis. Incorrect Options: Options B - Neurofibroma: Neurofibromas are benign tumors that arise from nerve tissue. They are more commonly found in peripheral nerves. Option C - Pericardial cyst: Pericardial cysts are fluid-filled sacs that develop in the pericardium, the sac surrounding the heart. Option D - Bronchogenic cyst: Bronchogenic cysts are congenital abnormalities that arise from abnormal development of the lung bud during embryogenesis. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: A 45-year-old chronic smoker presents with pain in his right leg. Upon examination, the pulse in the bilateral popliteal fossa is absent, and he experiences pain in the both buttock . Which level block is most likely present?
questions.explanation: popliteal fossa and pain in both buttocks, are indicative of aortoiliac artery disease. Aortoiliac artery disease commonly presents with buttock, thigh, and calf claudication, which is pain or cramping in the muscles of the lower extremities during physical activity. This condition is often associated with atherosclerosis, especially in chronic smokers like the patient described. Incorrect Options: Option A - Femoral Artery Disease: Common femoral artery disease typically presents with thigh and calf claudication, rather than pain in the buttocks. In this condition, the patient may experience pain or cramping in the muscles of the thigh and calf during physical activity due to inadequate blood supply. Option C - Popliteal Artery Disease: Popliteal artery disease usually manifests as calf claudication, not pain in the buttocks. Patients with popliteal artery disease may experience pain or cramping in the calf muscles during physical activity due to reduced blood flow to the lower leg. Option D - Iliac Artery Disease: While iliac artery disease can cause symptoms similar to aortoiliac artery disease, such as buttock, thigh, and calf claudication, the absent pulses in the bilateral popliteal fossa are not characteristic of isolated iliac artery disease. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: The most commonly involved artery in pseudoaneurysm formation :
questions.explanation: formation. It is a large artery located in the groin area and is frequently accessed for arterial catheterization or invasive procedures such as angiography, cardiac catheterization, or arterial line placement. Pseudoaneurysms can occur as a complication of these procedures due to the puncture and subsequent incomplete closure of the artery, leading to the formation of a pulsating hematoma. Incorrect Option: Option A - Aorta: While the aorta can develop aneurysms, a pseudoaneurysm, also known as a false aneurysm, is less commonly associated with the aorta. Option C - Popliteal artery: The popliteal artery is located behind the knee and is also susceptible to pseudoaneurysm formation. However, compared to the femoral artery, pseudoaneurysms in the popliteal artery are less common. Popliteal artery pseudoaneurysms can occur due to trauma, iatrogenic injury, or underlying vascular diseases affecting the artery. Option D - None of the above: This option is incorrect as both the femoral artery (Option B) and the popliteal artery (Option C) can be involved in pseudoaneurysm formation, with the femoral artery being the more commonly involved artery. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: On the 5 th postoperative day post CABG, the patient develops tachypnea and hypotension . What is the most probable cause?
questions.explanation: the lungs fail to provide adequate oxygenation to the body or efficiently remove carbon dioxide. Tachypnea (rapid breathing) and hypotension can be signs of inadequate oxygenation and perfusion. After CABG, potential causes of acute respiratory failure can include atelectasis (collapsed lung), pneumonia, pulmonary embolism, or other complications affecting lung function. Prompt evaluation and intervention are crucial to address respiratory compromise. Incorrect Options: Option A - Sepsis : Sepsis is a severe systemic infection that can cause various symptoms, including tachypnea and hypotension. However, without additional information, it is less likely to be the most probable cause on the 5th postoperative day after CABG. Other signs such as fever, elevated white blood cell count, or evidence of infection would be important to consider for a definitive diagnosis of sepsis. Option B - Acute kidney failure : Acute kidney failure, also known as acute renal failure, primarily affects kidney function and may manifest as decreased urine output, fluid overload, electrolyte disturbances, or changes in laboratory parameters such as elevated creatinine levels. While it can cause hypotension, tachypnea is not a typical symptom of acute kidney failure. Therefore, it is less likely to be the most probable cause in this scenario. Option D - Acute cardiac failure : Acute cardiac failure, also known as acute heart failure or congestive heart failure, typically presents with symptoms such as shortness of breath, fatigue, fluid retention, and signs of poor cardiac output. While acute cardiac failure can cause hypotension, tachypnea alone is less commonly associated with this condition. Other cardiac symptoms, such as edema, jugular venous distention, or abnormal heart sounds, would be important to consider for a definitive diagnosis of acute cardiac failure. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: While washing clothes in cold water, a female patient exhibits color changes in her hands from white to red . Which of the following drugs is best suited for this patient?
questions.explanation: the patient is experiencing Raynaud's phenomenon. In this condition, the blood vessels in the fingers and toes spasm and temporarily restrict blood flow. This can cause the affected areas to turn white, blue, and red. Cold temperatures or emotional stress can trigger the spasms. The best-suited drug for this patient would be a calcium channel blocker. These drugs work by relaxing the smooth muscle in the blood vessel walls, which can help to prevent or reduce the frequency of vasospasms. Calcium channel blockers are often used as first-line therapy for Raynaud's phenomenon. Incorrect Options: Option A - ACE inhibitors: ACE inhibitors are a type of blood pressure medication that works by blocking the production of angiotensin II, a hormone that can constrict blood vessels. However, they are ineffective in treating vasospastic disorders like Raynaud's phenomenon. Option C - Thiazides: Thiazides are a type of diuretic used to treat high blood pressure and edema, but they do not affect the blood vessels in a way that would be useful for treating Raynaud's phenomenon. Option D - Alpha-blockers: Alpha-blockers are another type of blood pressure medication that blocks the alpha receptors on blood vessel walls, causing them to relax and dilate. However, alpha-blockers are ineffective in treating Raynaud's phenomenon because they do not target the underlying vasospasms. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following provides long-lasting results in a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) ?
questions.explanation: long-lasting results in a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG). Coronary artery bypass grafting is a surgical procedure that is used to improve blood flow to the heart muscle by bypassing blocked or narrowed coronary arteries. During the procedure, a healthy blood vessel from another part of the body is grafted onto the blocked or narrowed artery, creating a new route for blood to flow to the heart. The internal mammary artery is located inside the chest, and it supplies blood to the chest wall and the heart muscle. It is an ideal vessel for CABG because it is resistant to the development of atherosclerosis (a buildup of plaque inside the artery), which can lead to re-narrowing or blockage of the grafted vessel over time. Incorrect Options: Option A - Long saphenous vein: The long saphenous vein is often used in CABG procedures, may develop atherosclerosis and become blocked over time, leading to the need for repeat surgeries. Option C - Poly tetra fluoro eythlene (PTFE): PTFE is a synthetic material that can be used in CABG, but it may also develop atherosclerosis over time. Option D - Gastroepiploic artery: The gastroepiploic artery is another option, but it is not as commonly used as the internal mammary artery. Reference: Prepladder Notes
